ac:adf-parameter.ac:adf-parameter: Create a reusable content block that can be included on other pages

p: The templates below are the defined Best Practices for US Full Stack clients. For some workflows these are consistent across all client verticals/leagues. For others, there is a defined Best Practice per vertical/league.

If your client is looking for a workflow outside of these best practices, please consult a Solutions Architect for a consultation. These Templates (Best Practices) should only be updated by an Architect.
These Best Practices are used to create client-specific Blueprints detailing how each of our clients use our system.

ac:rich-text-body.p: For more information on the MultiExcerpts that were used to create these Best Practices, refer to https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/cs/pages/4222746625.
{{para-fundamentals-intro}}

td.p: StandardGreen Market-driven resale on SeatGeek Open

StandardGreen Deposit/Waitlist pages hosted on SeatGeek site and app
StandardGreen Amplify access to all modules (including Analytics) for ticket office managers
StandardGreen {{league-or-vertical}} environment configuration, dictionary, and workflows
StandardGreen {{mobile-only-or-first}} ticket fulfillment and distribution for all regular buyers, with some exceptions

All ticketed parking is located at {{primary-venue}}, with {{qty-parking-areas}} parking lots ({{qty-parking-spots}} parking spots in total), with a majority of spots sold to full {{subscriber-caption}}s.

Yellow cells indicate the {{client}} ticket office has some reliance upon an application for minor or secondary ticketing operations. The ticket office may be trained on specifically solutioned usages of the application, but do not receive general-purpose training.
Red cells indicate the {{client}} ticket office has no plans to use an application, no solutioning nor diligence has been conducted, and staff will not receive training.

The concept of Organization Units within Unify (SRO) is not yet documented in the SeatGeek Knowledge Center. For now, the internal - seatgeek only https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1osKBSrejShs94gPRyA7UWznVX583y3tc/edit?usp=sharing&ouid=108111768379143683831&rtpof=true&sd=true document serves as SeatGeek’s most authoritative general-purpose documentation on Organization Units.
The {{client}} Unify (SRO) environment will contain one main organization unit, The {{Parent-or-Master}} Company, for all human users as well as the SeatGeek API.

If and when any Distribution Partners are activated, they will utilize their own organization units, set up as Sellers. These are automatically generated through provisioning the distribution partner's membership within the {{client}} SeatGeek Open domain. Distribution Partners' organization units will all be prefixed with DPO_; a StubHub organization unit, for example, would be DPO_StubHub.

If any SeatGeekIQ service is activated, it will operate within the The {{Parent-or-Master}} Company organization unit, for the purposes of fulfilling tickets through the SeatGeek platform as opposed to a third-party fulfillment service.

p.a: Users: Creating and managing employee and third-party access to your SRO environment
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SRO/pages/3042410518

ac:rich-text-body.p: On the {{client}} side, Users are created for each human or virtual user. Every User will be assigned to the appropriate Profile and Security Token.

Client users are created via the traditional native access provisioning process in the Unify (SRO) Admin module. These Users log in using Unify native login, on {{client-unify-URL}} or {{client-unify-URL}}/noSSO.

On the SeatGeek side, human Users are provisioned automatically through the SRO Identity Platform for single sign-on (SSO) authentication. These Users log in through the /SSO login page using SeatGeek Okta as the identity provider.
Virtual Users for SeatGeek (such as the SeatGeek API, SeatGeek Packages API, and other non-human sale flows) are provisioned through the native access provisioning process in the Admin module.

p.a: Users: Creating and managing employee and third-party access to your SRO environment
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SRO/pages/3042410518

ac:rich-text-body.p: On the {{client}} side, Users are created for each human or virtual user. Every User will be assigned to the appropriate Profile and Security Token.

The {{client}} organization has implemented Single Sign-On (SSO) access for their employees. They are using {{identity-provider}} as their identity provider. Users log into Unify through {{client-unify-URL}} or {{client-unify-URL}}/SSO.

The {{client}} organization has User Provisioning turned {{user-prov-ON-OFF}}. This controls whether new users can be created automatically at login time and do not need to be pre-created in the Unify (SRO) Admin module. The {{client}} organization is controlling permissions via the {{IdP-OR-std-Unify-config}}. If the {{client}} organization is controlling User permissions within the identity provider then {{client}} personnel within Unify (SRO) can only select the User Roles to which they’ve been granted access within {{identity-provider}}.

On the SeatGeek side, human Users are provisioned automatically through the SRO Identity Platform for single sign-on (SSO) authentication. These Users log in through the /SSO login page using SeatGeek Okta as the identity provider.
Virtual Users for SeatGeek (such as the SeatGeek API, SeatGeek Packages API, and other non-human sale flows) are provisioned through the native access provisioning process in the Admin module.

h2: STANDARDGreen Profiles, Security Tokens, and User Roles

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [all] Profiles, Security Tokens, and User Roles

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: [ALL] Profiles, Security Tokens, and User Roles

p.a: Profiles: Controlling the user interface for personnel
Security Tokens: Controlling data access and privileges for groups of users
User Roles: Permitting temporary permissions to SRO users

ac:rich-text-body.p: For {{client}} ticket office personnel, the corresponding assignment of Profiles and Security Tokens to Users follows the standard approach. The administration of users' access and permissions within the system is left to the discretion of {{client}} ticket office management. For Single Sign-On (SSO) Users, {{client}} may have either the external identity provider or Unify control which User Roles a user can access.

In practice, this means that elevated high-level permissions (such as access to all system modules and menus) as well as elevated lower-level permissions (such as the ability to sell unallocated or non-exclusively allocated inventory) is generally only available to Admin-level users such as ticket office directors and management, as is standard for most organizations.
For SeatGeek personnel, Users are provisioned access to the {{client}} Unify (SRO) environment via Single Sign-On (SSO). The standard Profiles and Security Tokens are permissioned as follows:

td.p: Mostly the same permissions as SG Admin, but cannot access xCustomizer nor Edit items PRICE.
Mostly the same permissions as SG Limited Admin.
Mostly the same permissions as SG Limited Admin.
Access to only the Sales and CRM modules. Cannot access xCustomizer nor Edit items PRICE.
Used by a sub-team within the SeatGeek Fan Support (FS) team. Has very limited CRM viewing permissions
Security Token assigned to any SG FS Profiles. Note that this is only a Security Token; there is no corresponding SG FS Profile.
Assigned to SeatGeek online single-{{event-caption}} sale flow(s), unless otherwise overridden.
Assigned to SeatGeek online {{series-caption}} sale flow(s), unless otherwise overridden.
Assigned to SeatGeek online {{subs-ticket-caption}} exchange flows, unless otherwise overridden.
Assigned to SeatGeek online {{subs-ticket-caption}} relocations flow, unless otherwise overridden.
Used by SeatGeek employees who are allowed to edit or modify SG Fees price modifiers and rules. Uses the SG View Profile and Security Token.
Abbreviation of SeatGeek Machine to Machine; used exclusively by the sg_maestro_api user for infrastructural purposes. Has no access to any menus or screens in the Unify UI.

ac:rich-text-body.p: The following User Roles are also available as alternates for SeatGeek personnel:

This role is only available to users with SG Admin access. Its Profile or Security Token can be edited to match that of a given {{client}} user as needed for the purposes of replicating reported issues.
This role grants access to editing or modifying the SG Fees price modifier’s definitions and rules.

{{client}} sell and distribute all major categories of ticketed products that are typical of {{league-or-vertical}} organizations.

Most of their business is done through full {{subscription-caption}} packages, single-{{event-caption}} tickets, multi-{{event-caption}} premium/hospitality tickets, and third-party {{event-caption}} tickets.

p.a: User reference guide: Sales and CRM (Unify)
User reference guide: Events (Build)

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} single-{{event-caption}} tickets are sold online and through the back office.

Tickets are sold online through SeatGeek event pages as the first-class distribution partner, while back office sales are conducted by sales representatives, box office window sellers, and ticket office management alike.

td.p: {{client}} service reps as well as ticket office managers conduct back office sales of single-event tickets to some extent. This is principally done for group, hospitality, and premium sales, or as a service to {{subscriber-caption}}s who are interested in purchasing single-{{event-caption}} add-on tickets.
Corporate partners or sponsors may have tickets sold onto their accounts by a Sponsorships department sales rep, or another ticket office user.

Walkup sales are conducted by box office personnel at the venue on {{event-caption}} days. {{client}} use {{crm-id-or-quick-sell}} to sell walkups. The box office is not open on non-{{event-caption}} days.

Any walkup sales which are sold onto customers' own CRM records and/or onto ‘dummy’ CRMs are typically fulfilled via SMS tickets at sale time, though box office personnel are trained to walk buyers through account linking if preferred.
Hard-stock printed tickets are not offered to walkup buyers, except for special circumstances left to the discretion of the {{client}} ticket office management.
Online sales of single-{{event-caption}} tickets are primarily conducted through SeatGeek as a first-class distribution partner.

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{primary-venue}} hosts third-party events, which are ticketed on the SeatGeek platform alongside regular {{league-or-vertical}} {{event-caption}}s. The details of the {{primary-venue}} third-party events arrangement are as follows:
{{client}} sell one full-{{subscription-caption}} for the {{league-or-vertical}} season, in addition to partial-{{subscription-caption}}s.
{{client}} sell one full-{{subscription-caption}} for the NFL season, in addition to {{subscription-caption}}s for parking and premium (suite or club) passes.
{{client}} sell both full and partial-{{subscription-caption}}s for the NHL season, in addition to {{subscription-caption}}s for parking and premium (suite or club) passes.

p.a: User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} sell a full {{subscription-caption}} package. This package contains a ticket to every {{event-caption}} in the MLS league-play season, including preseason matches, as well as right-of-refusal over their seats to both midseason tournaments (such as the US Open Cup) and for any home postseason MLS Cup playoff {{events-caption}}.
The full {{subscription-caption}} package is configured as follows:

td.p: Quantity of tickets is typically at least 20 at the start of the season: 17 regular-season home matches, plus 3 miscellaneous matches of another nature (friendlies, non-league play cup ties, etc.)
The printing policy is always set to print Both free-choice and auto-selected tickets.

Use Access Control is left disabled on the series, as it is not necessary to be enabled in order to print subscriber ({{event-caption}}-level) tickets. {{client}} do not print subscriber cards nor any other document types that require {{subscription-caption}}-level barcodes.
The series launches for new sales initially as an ‘empty’ series (containing no linked events), using series-based pricing.
After the upcoming {{league-or-vertical}} season’s schedule is released, the Event Release wizard is used to link the individual events to the series, and event-based pricing is put into effect.
After switching to event-based pricing through the Event Release wizard, {{client}} can vary pricing from game to game in the {{subscription-caption}} at their discretion.

The full {{subscription-caption}} package is prorated as {{events-caption}} pass. The series' event-based pricing policy automatically adjusts the sale price downward as matches pass and the Quantity of tickets included within it decreases. Once enough of the season’s {{events-caption}} have passed, the full season ticket package is taken off-sale by the {{client}} ticket office.

{{client}} sometimes will offer mid-season cancellations of full {{subscription-caption}} packages. The refundable amount is prorated based on the number and value of future matches; past matches are typically not refunded. Exceptions may be made by ticket office management to offer ‘full refunds’ including for past matches to {{subscriber-caption}}s. Crediting is done in the form of either {{deposits-caption}}s or direct reimbursements such as credit card refunds.

Full {{subscription-caption}} packages are sold both online and through the back office by certain ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the {{seatgeek-plans-or-mmc}} platform.

p.a: User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} sell a full {{subscription-caption}} package. This package contains a ticket to every game in the NBA regular season, including preseason games, as well as right-of-refusal over their seats to any home playoff games.
The full season ticket package is configured as follows:

td.p: Quantity of tickets is 43 at the start of the season; these 43 tickets constitute 41 regular-season home games plus 2 preseason games.
The printing policy is always set to print Both free-choice and auto-selected tickets.

Use Access Control is left disabled on the series, as it is not necessary to be enabled in order to print subscriber (event-level) tickets. {{client}} do not print subscriber cards nor any other document types that require {{subscription-caption}}-level barcodes.
The series launches for new sales initially as an ‘empty’ series (containing no linked events), using series-based pricing.
After the upcoming NBA season’s schedule is released, the Event Release wizard is used to link the individual events to the {{subscription-caption}}, and event-based pricing is put into effect.

The Overlap allowed between some Child Series policy setting is used heavily to specify which sales of the full {{subscription-caption}}'s child series (also known as its subseries, or partial-{{subscription-caption}} packages) will result in the same seat being blocked (marked as occupied) within other partial-plans' manifests.
After switching to event-based pricing through the Event Release wizard, {{client}} can vary pricing from game to game in the {{subscription-caption}} at their discretion.
{{client}} define distinct ‘pricing tiers' which dictate the values and revenue shares of events within the full {{subscription-caption}}. {{pricing-tier-details}}

The full season ticket package is prorated as games pass. The series' event-based pricing policy automatically adjusts the sale price downward as games pass and the Quantity of tickets included within it decreases. Once enough of the season’s games have passed, the full season ticket package is taken off-sale by the {{client}} ticket office.

If the need arises to prorate a game out of the plan prior to the game taking place, the linkage of the event to the {{series-caption}} will be changed from Linked to Recommended at the event level, and the Minimum quantity of tickets on the {{series-caption} definition is reduced. The {{series-caption}} can then be sold without a subscriber ticket to the forthcoming event included by default, but a seller has the option of adding it manually at sale time. This is often useful when processing exchanges or mid-season relocations for {{subscribers-caption}}.

{{client}} sometimes will offer mid-season cancellations of full {{subscription-caption}} packages. The refundable amount is prorated based on the number and value of future games; past games are typically not refunded. Exceptions may be made by ticket office management to offer ‘full refunds’ including for past games to season ticket members. Crediting is done in the form of either deposits or direct reimbursements such as credit card refunds.
Full season ticket packages are sold both online and through the back office by certain ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the SeatGeek Plans platform.

Full {{subscription-caption}} packages are sold both online and through the back office by certain ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the {{seatgeek-plans-or-mmc}} platform.

p.a: User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} sell a full {{subscription-caption}} package. This package contains a ticket to every {{event-caption}} in their tournament.
The full {{subscription-caption}} package is configured as follows:

td.p: Quantity of tickets is equal to the total number of matches occurring at their tournament.
The printing policy is always set to print Both free-choice and auto-selected tickets.

Use Access Control is left disabled on the series, as it is not necessary to be enabled in order to print subscriber ({{event-caption}}-level) tickets. {{client}} do not print subscriber cards nor any other document types that require {{subscription-caption}}-level barcodes.
The series launches for new sales initially as an ‘empty’ series (containing no linked events), using series-based pricing.
After the upcoming {{league-or-vertical}} season’s schedule is released, the Event Release wizard is used to link the individual events to the series, and event-based pricing is put into effect.
After switching to event-based pricing through the Event Release wizard, {{client}} can vary pricing from match to match in the {{subscription-caption}} at their discretion.

The full {{subscription-caption}} package is prorated as matches pass. The series' event-based pricing policy automatically adjusts the sale price downward as matches pass and the Quantity of tickets included within it decreases. Once enough of the tournaments matches have passed, the full season ticket package is taken off-sale by the {{client}} ticket office.

{{client}} sometimes will offer mid-tournament cancellations of full {{subscription-caption}} packages. The refundable amount is prorated based on the number and value of future matches; past matches are typically not refunded. Exceptions may be made by ticket office management to offer ‘full refunds’ including for past matches to {{subscriber-caption}}s. Crediting is done in the form of either {{deposits-caption}}s or direct reimbursements such as credit card refunds.

Full {{subscription-caption}} packages are sold both online and through the back office by certain ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the {{seatgeek-plans-or-mmc}} platform.

p.a: User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} sell a {{subscription-caption}} package product. This package is linked only to the single-event ticket of the bowl game itself; it consists of exactly one subscriber ticket.
The package is configured as follows:

td.p: Quantity of tickets is set to 1.
The printing policy is always set to print Both free-choice and auto-selected tickets.

Use Access Control is left disabled on the series, as it is not necessary to be enabled in order to print subscriber ({{event-caption}}-level) tickets. {{client}} do not print subscriber cards nor any other document types that require {{subscription-caption}}-level barcodes.
The series launches for new sales initially as an ‘empty’ series (containing no linked events), using series-based pricing.

After the bowl matchup is announced and its kickoff time is confirmed, the Event Release wizard is used to link the individual bowl game event (and only that event) to the series, and event-based pricing is put into effect.
After switching to event-based pricing through the Event Release wizard, {{client}} sets the price of the one-game season ticket product through the event’s Subscriber Tickets Price List.
{{subscription-caption}} packages are sold both online and through the back office by ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the {{seatgeek-plans-or-mmc}} platform.

p.a: User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages
Parent series and child series hierarchy
Managing inventory (seat attributes) across parent and children series' associated events
Child series overlapping policies
Fixed series
Flex series
Mixed series

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} may, depending on demand, sell one or more partial {{subscription-caption}} packages in a given {{league-or-vertical}} season. These may be fixed, flex, or mixed {{subscription-caption}} plans; in all cases, these partial {{subscription-caption}} plans will be configured as ‘child’ series, related and subordinate to the ‘parent’ full {{subscription-caption}} series.
A few examples of the partial {{subscription-caption}} packages that {{client}} sell are below.
{{client}} generally do not sell any partial {{subscription-caption}} packages for the NFL season.
Fixed series, from User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages

{{client}} sell partial {{subscription-caption}} fixed plans, also sometimes referred to as ‘mini-plans.' In a fixed plan, every {{event-caption}} is required and default-selected; buyers do not select which events they want to attend. Buyers select the seat that they’d like to sit in within the partial plan, and they will be seated within the same seat for every {{event-caption}} within the plan.
Fixed partial plans are configured as follows:

td.p: The partial {{subscription-caption}} series is Seated, and is assigned to the same {{hall-caption}} and {{hall-caption}} Version as the parent full {{subscription-caption}} series.
Quantity of tickets will vary, depending on what the plan offering is. In most cases, partial plans will consist of fewer than half the number of events that the full {{subscription-caption}} does.
The printing policy is always set to print Both free-choice and auto-selected tickets.

Use Access Control is left disabled on the series, as it is not necessary to be enabled in order to print subscriber ({{event-caption}}-level) tickets. {{client}} do not print subscriber cards nor any other document types that require {{subscription-caption}}-level barcodes.
Partial plans launch for new sales with all of their events already manually linked.

Fixed partial {{subscription-caption}} plans may use either series-based pricing or event-based pricing, depending on whether {{client}} wish to variably-weight the revenue value of the events within the plan.
In most cases, partial {{subscription-caption}} plans will not be prorated as events pass; after the first {{event-caption}} within a plan passes, the plan is usually taken off-sale.

{{client}} sometimes offer cancellations of partial {{subscription-caption}} packages. The refundable amount is prorated based on the number and value of future events; past events are typically not refunded. Exceptions may be made by ticket office management to offer ‘full refunds’ including for past events to partial-plan {{subscriber-caption}}s. Crediting is done in the form of either {{deposits-caption}}s or direct reimbursements such as credit card refunds.

Partial {{subscription-caption}} packages are sold both online and through the back office by certain ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the SeatGeek Plans platform.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Flex series, from User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages
{{client}} sell partial {{subscription-caption}} flex plans, also sometimes referred to as ‘pick-plans.'

In a flex plan, all events are optional: buyers select the specific events they want to attend first, then select the seat(s) they’d like to sit in for each event. If the seat location they’ve chosen within a given event is available in other events that they’d selected, the SeatGeek Plans online sale flow will offer to cart the same seat location for those events.
Flex plans are generally configured as follows:

td.p: Quantity of tickets will vary, depending on what the plan offering is. In most cases, flex plans will consist of fewer than half the number of events that the full {{subscription-caption}} does.
The printing policy is always set to print Both free-choice and auto-selected tickets.

Use Access Control is left disabled on the series, as it is not necessary to be enabled in order to print subscriber ({{event-caption}}-level) tickets. {{client}} do not print subscriber cards nor any other document types that require {{subscription-caption}}-level barcodes.
Flex plans' selectable events are defined as Recommended within the series.
Flex plans use event-based pricing. Event-based pricing allows {{client}} to attenuate demand for selectable events within the plan, while also variably-weighting the revenue value of the events.

In most cases, flex plans will not be prorated as events pass; after the first {{event-caption}} within a plan passes, the plan is usually taken off-sale. In cases where prorating of a plan is offered, event-based pricing is recommended.

{{client}} rarely offer cancellations or refunds for flex plan purchases. In cases where exceptions are made, the refundable amount is prorated based on the number and value of future events; past events are typically not refunded. Further exceptions may be made by ticket office management to offer ‘full refunds’ including for past events to flex plan buyers. Crediting is done in the form of either {{deposits-caption}}s or direct reimbursements such as credit card refunds.
Flex plans are sold both online and through the back office by certain ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the SeatGeek Plans platform.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Mixed series, from User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages
{{client}} sell partial {{subscription-caption}} mixed plans.

In a mixed plan, some events are optional while others are required. The required events are selected by default and cannot be unselected, and buyers will select the additional specific events they want to attend as well. After completing their event selections, they will then select the seat(s) they’d like to sit in for each event. If the seat location they’ve chosen within a given event is available in other events that they’d selected, the SeatGeek Plans online sale flow will offer to cart the same seat location for those events.
Mixed plans are generally configured as follows:

td.p: Quantity of tickets will vary, depending on what the plan offering is. In most cases, mixed plans will consist of fewer than half the number of events that the full {{subscription-caption}} does.
The printing policy is always set to print Both free-choice and auto-selected tickets.

Use Access Control is left disabled on the series, as it is not necessary to be enabled in order to print subscriber ({{event-caption}}-level) tickets. {{client}} do not print subscriber cards nor any other document types that require {{subscription-caption}}-level barcodes.
Mixed plans' required (non-selectable) events are defined as Linked to the series, and are Required.
Mixed plans' selectable events are defined as Recommended within the series, and not Required.
Mixed plans use event-based pricing. Event-based pricing allows {{client}} to attenuate demand for selectable events within the plan, while also variably-weighting the revenue value of the events.

In most cases, mixed plans will not be prorated as events pass; after the first {{event-caption}} within a plan passes, the plan is usually taken off-sale. In cases where prorating of a plan is offered, event-based pricing is recommended.

{{client}} rarely offer cancellations or refunds for mixed plan purchases. In cases where exceptions are made, the refundable amount is prorated based on the number and value of future events; past events are typically not refunded. Further exceptions may be made by ticket office management to offer ‘full refunds’ including for past events to mixed plan buyers. Crediting is done in the form of either {{deposits-caption}}s or direct reimbursements such as credit card refunds.
Mixed plans are sold both online and through the back office by certain ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the SeatGeek Plans platform.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Mixed series, from User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages

p.a: https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/FAN/pages/4026105875

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} sell partial {{subscription-caption}} bucket plans, also sometimes referred to as ‘tiered’ plans.

Bucket plans are similar to ‘mixed’ plans. In a bucket plan, some events are optional while others are required. The required events are selected by default and cannot be unselected, and buyers will select the additional specific events they want to attend as well. What distinguishes a bucket plan from a mixed plan is that the sale flow is able to contain different buckets (groups/categories/tiers) of events, and mandate that a minimum (or maximum) number of events must be selected from within each bucket.

After completing their event selections, they will then select the seat(s) they’d like to sit in for each event. If the seat location they’ve chosen within a given event is available in other events that they’d selected, the SeatGeek Plans online sale flow will offer to cart the same seat location for those events.
Bucket plans are generally configured as follows:

td.p: Quantity of tickets will vary, depending on what the plan offering is. In most cases, bucket plans will consist of fewer than half the number of events that the full {{subscription-caption}} does.
The printing policy is always set to print Both free-choice and auto-selected tickets.

Use Access Control is left disabled on the series, as it is not necessary to be enabled in order to print subscriber ({{event-caption}}-level) tickets. {{client}} do not print subscriber cards nor any other document types that require {{subscription-caption}}-level barcodes.
Bucket plans' required (non-selectable) events are defined as Linked to the series, and are Required.
Bucket plans' selectable events are defined as Recommended within the series, and not Required.
Buckets are defined with a Name and Description within the {{series-caption}} area of the Content module.
Events are allocated with Buckets in the Linkage Details section of each event’s own {{subscription-caption}}s tab.
The minimum and/or maximum quantity of selectable events within a given Bucket is defined by the SeatGeek team internally, per the {{client}} ticket office’s requirements.
Bucket plans use event-based pricing. Event-based pricing allows {{client}} to attenuate demand for selectable events within the plan, while also variably-weighting the revenue value of the events.

In most cases, bucket plans will not be prorated as events pass; after the first {{event-caption}} within a plan passes, the plan is usually taken off-sale. In cases where prorating of a plan is offered, event-based pricing is recommended.

{{client}} rarely offer cancellations or refunds for bucket plan purchases. In cases where exceptions are made, the refundable amount is prorated based on the number and value of future events; past events are typically not refunded. Further exceptions may be made by ticket office management to offer ‘full refunds’ including for past events to bucket plan buyers. Crediting is done in the form of either {{deposits-caption}}s or direct reimbursements such as credit card refunds.
Bucket plans are sold both online and through the back office by certain ticket office personnel. Online sales are conducted on SeatGeek, using the SeatGeek Plans platform.

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [horse racing]Yellow [Horse Racing] Combo Ticket Event Packages

p.a: Combo Tickets: Building multi-day events for sale on SeatGeek.com

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} offer Combo Ticket packages, which are commonly used for multi-day events, but are presented through the single event sales flow on http://SeatGeek.com rather than through SeatGeek Plans.
Customers will see the Combo Ticket package sold within the single-Event sales flow as one combined event that includes tickets for multiple days.

td.p: Each day of the multi-day Event will need its own Event & Event Template. Every event ticket that is to be included in the Combo Ticket product must later be linked to the Combo Ticket Series.

The “Shell” Event only needs to be “built” to the extent that is necessary for the SeatGeek Open Recon system to scrape the event, generate the SeatGeek Event ID, and map the Unify Event to the http://SeatGeek.com Event.

This “Shell” Event is meant to contain all of the Events (representing each day of the multi-day offering) in the Combo Tickets package, and is what will be used for the sale of this product on http://SeatGeek.com (as opposed to through the SeatGeek Plans or Storefront system).

For a Combo Tickets product, the Series created sets the actual business rules of the product. The Series manifest (Locks and Allocations, Pricing, etc.) as well as its other rules (Fees, Limitations, etc.) control the behavior of the Combo Ticket purchase flow, much like how those policies are typically set for single-Event purchase flows at the Event product level.

Each of the multi-day Events that the package includes are to be linked to the Series in order to be sold together within the package. The “Shell” Event does not get linked to the Series and will act as a standalone event.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Combo Tickets are presented to the buyer as a single “shell” Event ticket, but are configured and managed in the back office as the sale of a Series product within Unify, with each individual day’s Event linked to the Series and able to be managed as individual event tickets.

p.a: User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages
SeatGeek Exchanges: Enabling subscriber ticket exchanges online

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} offer ‘voucher’-style packages, through which a customer can pre-pay for a set of vouchers that they can redeem for tickets to {{events-caption}} over the course of the season. Relative to a full {{subscription-caption}} or a flex plan, voucher packs provide fans an affordable and flexible option to attend {{events-caption}} when they like.
The basic voucher purchase and redemption process that a customer goes through is:

li.p: A voucher pack {{subscription-caption}} is purchased, usually online through SeatGeek Plans. The voucher pack contains a set number of ‘dummy event' subscriber tickets, which on their own are not valid tickets and cannot be used for entry to any {{client}} {{events-caption}}. These dummy event tickets serve as the customer’s redeemable 'vouchers.'

Through the online SeatGeek Exchanges experience, the fan redeems their voucher by exchanging their dummy event ticket(s) for tickets to ‘real’ {{events-caption}}. All voucher redemptions are even-exchanges: the value (price) of the dummy ticket being exchanged-out is equal to the price of the voucher-specific price type for tickets to ‘real’ {{events-caption}}. The fan does not need to pay any additional amount to redeem their voucher.

ac:rich-text-body.p: The {{client}} voucher pack, branded as the {{voucher-pack-name}}, is sold online as a fixed {{subscription-caption}}, configured accordingly:

td.p: At the beginning of the season, the voucher pack contains {{qty-of-tickets}}. As {{events-caption}} pass, the voucher pack {{is-or-is-not}} prorated.

Voucher ‘dummy’ events are built and linked as required within the voucher pack series, so that the purchase of a voucher pack subscription issues the customer subscriber tickets which are later redeemed for tickets to actual {{client}} {{events-caption}}.

The ‘dummy’ events are not visible for sale online nor in the back office, and cannot be bought as standalone tickets independent of the voucher pack. SG Online Ticket Management rules are set such that the subscriber tickets for these dummy events owned by voucher pack purchasers are not visible nor manageable in the SeatGeek app.
Although the dummy events are linked to the voucher pack series, and a customer can exchange out of those dummy events, a customer cannot exchange into another dummy event.
Although the dummy events are linked to the voucher pack series, and a customer can exchange out of those dummy events, a customer cannot exchange into another dummy event.

The ‘real’ {{events-caption}} in the {{client}} season are made eligible for exchanging into, although those ‘target’ {{events-caption}} are not themselves linked to the series; they are not included in the initial purchase of the voucher pack, but are the only {{events-caption}} that can be exchanged-into as part of the voucher pack.
Voucher packs are sold at one or more price types that are exclusively used only when selling the voucher pack product.

In the Subscriber Ticket Price List(s) of the target (exchange-in) {{events-caption}}, the voucher pack-specific price type(s) will be defined with a Price that equals the sale price (per-voucher) of all voucher pack sales.

For instance, if a 10-voucher pack sold for $150 originally, each voucher’s redemption value is $15. In order to ensure all voucher redemptions are even-exchanges, the Price in the subscriber ticket price list for all target events would in turn be set to $15.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Charging item {{fee-caption}}s on voucher pack sales is generally not recommended. Item {{fee-caption}}s are apportioned to the subscriber tickets (vouchers) and affect the redemption value (price) of the vouchers. For the simplest possible build and redemption flow for fans, charging item {{fee-caption}}s should be avoided.

If an item {{fee-caption}} must be charged on sales of voucher packs, the Return Policy on the definition of the fee can be set to not refund the {{fee-caption}} in exchange scenarios. Although this ensures that the redemption value of the ‘voucher’ is only the price of the voucher ticket (which makes setting the Price of of the target tickets easier), it’s important to note that declining to refund/return the item {{fee-caption}} in an exchange ‘orphans’ the {{fee-caption}} within the voucher ticket, and that {{fee-caption}} amount cannot be refunded or credited toward the customer at any point from that point onward.

Transaction {{fee-caption}}s can be assessed during the initial sale of the voucher pack; this type of fee will always be retained by the ticket office and will never affect or add to the redemption value of individual vouchers. Transaction {{fee-caption}}s can be returned or refunded when returning the voucher pack as a whole, if desired.

In addition to the Unify-side configuration above, voucher pack owners are presented an offer in {{client}} Account Manager to redeem their vouchers. This offer simply links to the SeatGeek Exchanges flow for the voucher pack series.

p.a: Renewals: Processing season ticket package annual renewals using SeatGeek Account Manager
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SRN/pages/3128098824

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} full {{subscriber-caption}}s are offered the option to renew their season tickets starting in {{annual-renewal-month}} each year.
Renewals are offered through Method 1 (Unpaid invoicing):

li.p: An offer is put up in SeatGeek Account Manager for {{subscriber-caption}}s to confirm their renewals and select their preferred payment method. Payment methods include pay-in-full (credit card and/or Automated Clearing House/ACH), and one or more payment plans.

At the end of the renewal window, non-actors – {{subscriber-caption}}s who did not confirm their renewal through the Account Manager offer -- are automatically opted-in (renewed) for the upcoming season. Non-actors are placed onto the default payment plan offered by {{client}}, which in most cases is a 6-month payment plan. Placement of non-actors onto the default 6-month payment plan is carried out manually, on an individual account-by-account basis, by sales/service representatives in the {{client}} ticket office.
{{client}} will also bulk draft invoice {{subscriber-caption}}s for their renewals, which provides them a downloadable PDF invoice containing their renewal terms and an itemized receipt.

Renewals (Full stack)

p.a: Relocations: Offering upgrades and downgrades to season ticket holders
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/FAN/pages/4346937396

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} offer a window in {{relo-window-month}} of each year during which full {{subscriber-caption}}s can relocate their {{subscription-caption}} packages through SeatGeek’s online relocation flow. Sales and service representatives will also process relocations manually through the back office, in some cases.

The online relocation flow can be accessed through direct links, or offers within SeatGeek Account Manager. {{subscriber-caption}}s are given an offer through which they can enter the relocation flow. Within the relocation flow, they can choose which of their seats that they wish to vacate – they may relocate some or all of their seats – and select the target (new) seat locations they wish to move into. Each seat that the {{subscriber-caption}} chooses to vacate must be replaced with a target seat in the online relocation flow; they can only drop any seats outright by contacting the {{client}} ticket office, who may then process the return through the back office.
{{para-add-ons}}

If a {{subscriber-caption}} chooses to upgrade (relocates to a more expensive seat), they will pay for the difference between the target seat and the vacated seat within SeatGeek Account Manager Checkout. {{client}} has the option to force {{subscriber-caption}}s to pay the difference in full at the time of relocation, or the {{subscriber-caption}} can pay the difference via a payment plan. If the {{subscriber-caption}} is already enrolled in an active payment plan with an open balance, they can apply the cost of the relocation toward their existing payment plan.

If a {{subscriber-caption}} chooses to downgrade (relocates to a cheaper seat), they will be reimbursed the difference in value between the target seat(s) and the vacated seat(s). This reimbursement will come in the form of a reduction in their payment plan balance (if they have an open balance) commensurate to the change in value, and/or {{deposit-caption}} within their CRM record.

Relocations that are processed by ticket office representatives through the back office are done via the Replace Seats function in the Unify Sales/CRM modules. Back office relocations permit the use of the Client’s Payment Plan payment method in upgrade scenarios, and also allow partial-drops of seats.

p.a: Relocations: Offering upgrades and downgrades to season ticket holders
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SRN/pages/2576253264

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} offer a window in {{relo-window-month}} of each year during which full {{subscriber-caption}}s can relocate their {{subscription-caption}} packages through an online relocation flow, powered by MMC. Sales and service representatives will also process relocations manually through the back office, in some cases.

The online relocation flow is hosted by MMC and embedded within SeatGeek Account Manager. {{subscriber-caption}}s are given an offer through which they can enter the relocation flow. Within the relocation flow, they can choose which of their seats that they wish to vacate – they may relocate some or all of their seats – and select the target (new) seat locations they wish to move into. Each seat that the {{subscriber-caption}} chooses to vacate must be replaced with a target seat in the online relocation flow; they cannot drop any seats outright without contacting the ticket office, who may then process the return through the back office.
{{para-add-ons}}

If a {{subscriber-caption}} chooses to upgrade (relocates to a more expensive seat), they will pay for the difference between the target seat and the vacated seat within SeatGeek Account Manager Checkout. {{client}} has the option to force {{subscriber-caption}}s to pay the difference in full at the time of relocation, or the {{subscriber-caption}} can pay the difference via a payment plan.

{{subscriber-caption}}s who relocate online using MMC do not have the option of adding the additional amount to pay onto their existing payment plan’s balance. To apply a relocation upgrade toward an open payment plan balance, SeatGeek’s in-house Relocations experience should be used.

If a {{subscriber-caption}} chooses to downgrade (relocates to a cheaper seat), they will be reimbursed the difference in value between the target seat and the vacated seat. This reimbursement will come in the form of a reduction in their payment plan balance (if they have an open balance) commensurate to the change in value, and/or a {{deposit-caption}}.

Relocations that are processed by ticket office representatives through the back office are done via the Replace Seats function in the Unify Sales/CRM modules. Back office relocations permit the use of the Client’s Payment Plan payment method in upgrade scenarios, and also allow partial-drops of seats.

p.a: SeatGeek Exchanges: Enabling subscriber ticket exchanges online
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SGO/pages/3820650574

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} allow {{subscriber-caption}}s to exchange seats to individual events ('subscriber tickets') that they own within their {{subscription-caption}} online through the SeatGeek Exchanges platform. Sales and service representatives will also process subscriber ticket exchanges manually through the back office, in some cases.

The online exchange flow is managed natively by SeatGeek, accessed through SeatGeek Account Manager, and does not depend on any third-party platforms. The online exchange option is generally only granted to full {{subscriber-caption}}s and is not usually made available to partial {{subscription-caption}} plan owners.

p.a: User reference guide: Ticket Schemes for playoffs and pay-as-we-play

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} full {{subscriber-caption}}s are given right-of-refusal for MLS Cup playoff match tickets. The process for offering, fulfilling, and/or declining playoff tickets leverages Unify (SRO)'s Ticket Schemes feature.
The MLS Cup playoffs are played through a mixture of best-of-3 and single-elimination rounds. The specifics of matchups and schedules for each round are detailed on mlssoccer.com:

blockquote.p: Seeds 1-7 in each conference will automatically qualify for the Round One Best-of-3 series.
Seeds 8-9 in each conference will qualify for MLS Cup Playoffs Wild Card matches.

p.strong: MLS Cup Playoffs Wild Card Matches (2 games; 1 for each conference)

blockquote.p: Two single-game elimination matches hosted by the higher seed.

p.strong: Round One Best-of-3 Series (8-16 games; 4-8 for each conference)

blockquote.p: Every Round One game will have a winner; no ties, no aggregate score.
The matches will be hosted in a home-away-home format:

p.strong: Conference Semifinals (4 games; 2 for each conference)

blockquote.p: Single-game elimination matches, hosted by the higher seed.

p.strong: Conference Final (2 games; 1 for each conference)

blockquote.p: Single-elimination match hosted by the higher seed.

p.strong: MLS Cup presented by Audi (1 game between the Conference Champions)

blockquote.p: A single match hosted by the higher seed.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Although the Round One Best-of-3 Series can potentially lead to the higher-seeded team hosting two home matches within the same round (Match 1 and Match 3), Match 3 is only played if it is necessary (resulting from a Match 2 win for the lower-seeded team). Because Match 3 is not guaranteed to be played before the round begins, SeatGeek does not recommend using fulfillment-by-round in Round One of the MLS Cup playoffs. If {{client}} wishes to fulfill Round One as a strip of two games, they would do so knowing that there is a chance that they will need to bulk return Match 3 tickets in the event that it goes unplayed.
For all other rounds of the MLS Cup playoffs, {{client}} will use game-by-game fulfillment.

{{client}} may offer their full {{subscriber-caption}}s the right-of-refusal for MLS Cup playoff match tickets. The process for offering, and/or opting out of playoff tickets leverages the Reservation Confirmation offering through SeatGeek Account Manager.
Playoff tickets are offered in a similar manner to utilizing Renewals Method 2, which consists of a Reservation confirmation offer, with or without invoicing.

li.p: An offer is put up in SeatGeek Account Manager for {{subscriber-caption}}s to confirm each round of offered Playoff tickets as the team advances. During the Reservation Confirmation opt in flow, users can select their preferred payment method. Payment methods could include the option to pay-in-full or utilization of payment plans, which would act in a ‘Pay as we Play’ manner, charging customers for games when they are confirmed they are being played.

At the end of the Playoff offer window, {{subscriber-caption}}s who did not confirm their Playoff tickets for that round or all potential events through the Account Manager offer would have their reservations cancelled and their optional playoff tickets dropped from their accounts.
{{client}} can also bulk draft invoice {{subscriber-caption}}s for their playoff tickets, which provides them a downloadable PDF invoice for the Playoff tickets they are being offered.

p.a: User reference guide: Ticket Schemes for playoffs and pay-as-we-play
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SGO/pages/3719659561

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} full {{subscriber-caption}}s are given right-of-refusal for NBA playoff game tickets. The process for offering, fulfilling, and/or declining playoff tickets leverages Unify (SRO)'s Ticket Schemes feature.
{{para-playoffs-offer}}

The NBA playoffs are played in rounds consisting of multiple guaranteed home games. A team playing in a playoff series will play at least 2 guaranteed games at home, and as many as 4 (if they are the higher-seeded team) or 3 (if they are the lower-seeded team). Because of this, it is standard for NBA teams to fulfill playoff tickets in advance to both guaranteed games within the upcoming round for every opted-in full {{subscriber-caption}}.
Fulfillment-by-round (sometimes referred to as ‘strips’) has two distinct advantages for the {{client}} over the more traditional game-by-game fulfillment method:

li.p: A single combined payment is collected from the {{subscriber-caption}} for both games at the same time, in one transaction, rather than a payment being collected for each game individually. This combined payment reduces the incremental costs associated with online payments.
The Ticket Schemes system’s fulfillment process (which depends upon successful payment being collected) completes more quickly, as there are fewer transactions to process.

ac:rich-text-body.p: After fulfilling the first two (guaranteed) home games in the round, a third (and/or fourth) fulfillable game is added to the round only after being confirmed to be played. Fulfillment of non-guaranteed games within a round is processed on a game-by-game basis.

p.a: User reference guide: Ticket Schemes for playoffs and pay-as-we-play
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SGO/pages/3719659561

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client} full {{subscriber-caption}}s who have committed to renew for the following season are given right-of-refusal for Stanley Cup playoffs tickets. The process for offering, fulfilling, and/or declining playoff tickets leverages Unify (SRO)'s Ticket Schemes feature.
{{para-playoffs-offer}}

The NHL playoffs are played in rounds consisting of multiple guaranteed home games. A team playing in a playoff series will play at least 2 guaranteed games at home, and as many as 4 (if they are the higher-seeded team) or 3 (if they are the lower-seeded team). Because of this, it is standard for NHL clubs to fulfill playoff tickets in advance to both guaranteed games within the upcoming round for every opted-in full {{subscriber-caption}}.
Fulfillment-by-round (sometimes referred to as ‘strips’) has two distinct advantages for the {{client}} over the more traditional game-by-game fulfillment method:

li.p: A single combined payment is collected from the {{subscriber-caption}} for both games at the same time, in one transaction, rather than a payment being collected for each game individually. This combined payment reduces the incremental costs associated with online payments.
The Ticket Schemes system’s fulfillment process (which depends upon successful payment being collected) completes more quickly, as there are fewer transactions to process.

ac:rich-text-body.p: After fulfilling the first two (guaranteed) home games in the round, a third (and/or fourth) fulfillable game is added to the round only after being confirmed to be played. Fulfillment of non-guaranteed games within a round is processed on a game-by-game basis.
The price of a playoff strip is heavily discounted, which {{client}} use to incentivize {{subscriber-caption}}s to renew their {{series-caption}} into the upcoming season.

p.a: User reference guide: Ticket Schemes for playoffs and pay-as-we-play

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} full {{subscriber-caption}}s are given right-of-refusal for NFL playoff game tickets. The process for offering, reserving, fulfilling, and/or declining playoff tickets leverages Unify (SRO)'s Ticket Schemes feature.

The NFL playoffs are played as a series of single-elimination games; the winner proceeds to the next game/opponent, while the loser’s season ends. Before playoffs begin, full {{subscriber-caption}}s are automatically enrolled in the {{ticket-scheme-caption}}. They are then are given the chance to opt into or out of their {{subscription-caption}} seats for all potential playoff home games.

{{subscriber-caption}}s can opt out of playoff tickets through an offer in SeatGeek Account Manager. The offer’s call-to-action links out to a Typeform survey, which will be {{client}}-branded and will consist of a few brief questions for the {{subscriber-caption}} to answer. {{subscriber-caption}}s who do not want to purchase playoff tickets in their regular {{subscription-caption}} seat locations will submit their survey response, and their response (as well as their CRM ID) will be recorded in a spreadsheet that is shared between SeatGeek and the {{client}} ticket office.

On a daily basis prior to the playoffs commencing, {{client}} will check the survey responses and ‘de-roll’ the respondents from the {{ticket-scheme-caption}}. By cancelling enrollments before game tickets are reserved or fulfilled onto the {{subscriber-caption}}s' accounts, opted-out {{subscriber-caption}}s will not be charged for playoff tickets, and their seat locations will then be offered to others, or be made sellable as open inventory for the game’s public onsale.
There are two ways that {{client}} {{subscriber-caption}}s can pay for playoff tickets:

li.p: As soon as a given playoff game is confirmed, the Unify (SRO) event is filled in with the relevant details (opponent, date and time, ticket management policies), and tickets for that game are fulfilled via the scheme. This process repeats for each round of the playoffs where {{client}} is the host (home team).

Alternatively, {{subscriber-caption}}s may pay in full, in advance of the playoffs, for all potential home games. For any {{subscriber-caption}}s who choose to pay in full, their tickets are fulfilled immediately upon paying, although event details such as opponent, date, and kickoff time may still be to-be-determined. Any playoff games that do not ultimately get played at home will be {{refunded-or-credited}} back to {{subscriber-caption}}s.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Playoff tickets generally will have the same SG Online Ticket Management policies as regular-season games.

On a daily basis prior to the playoffs commencing, {{client}} will check the survey responses and ‘de-roll’ the respondents from the {{ticket-scheme-caption}}. As soon as a playoff match is confirmed for each round, the Unify (SRO) events are filled in with the relevant details (opponent, date and time, ticket management policies), and tickets are ultimately fulfilled via the scheme. {{client}} have a dedicated team of representatives for suites and clubs, referred to broadly as their Premium Sales & Service department.

Each add-on event is mapped to SeatGeek Open, allowing owned tickets to be accessed and managed in the SeatGeek app/SDK as ‘nested' tickets within the main event ticket.

Areas within the regular, main-event manifest, made available for sale online as part of the main event.
They may have designated banners or digital ticket configurations to tell onsite staff that they are club tickets.

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} {{does-or-does-not}} carve out the ‘lift’ for each premium ticket sold using ‘Inside-out’ {{fee-caption}}s. These are regular, non-Inside {{fee-caption}}s that have The price displayed in the basket includes this fee enabled in their definition.

Lift is the portion of the seat’s revenue that is retained by {{client}} and is not shared/split with the {{league}} office. The portion of the sold seat’s revenue that is not carved-out as lift is the portion of the revenue that is shared with the league.
The Price of each seat within the Price List represents the ‘base price’ value of the seat; this is the revenue that is shared with the league.
The {{fee-caption}}s that {{client}} defines for their un-split, privately retained revenue are assigned as Item {{fee-caption}}s effective upon their Premium add-on events.

li.p: A Premium seat sells for $1000. This is the full amount that the customer pays.
Per league requirements, $250 of every Premium seat’s sale value must be shared between {{client}} and the league.
Thus, $750 of the $1000 in revenue is retained by {{client}}.

ac:rich-text-body.p: To support this arrangement, the following configurations are put in place:

li.p: {{client}} sets the Price in the Price List to $250. This is the ‘base price’ value that is split with the league.

{{client}} sets the lift’s {{fee-caption}} to $750 in the Item Fee rules assessed upon the event. This fee rule will also have the Automatically add to basket, but ALLOW manual removal as well as Users can edit value in basket = True parameters in place. This allows the Premium sales rep to override the lift value to a custom amount dictated by ticket office management, if needed.
Customer pays $1000 for the Premium seat (unless the $750 default lift value is overridden/customized by the rep at sale time).
When reporting on that Premium seat’s sale, {{client}} use the Sale value (less {{fee-caption}}s output column which reflects the $250 in shared revenue (the Price within the Price List).
{{client}} submits $250 in revenue for that seat to the league when settling upon revenue-share after the game is played.

p.a: Deposit and Waitlist sites: Collecting deposits online to apply toward future purchases or enrollments
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SRN/pages/1767932400

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} host pages on SeatGeek where customers can put down deposits of varying amounts for future larger-value purchases, such as full {{subscription-caption}}s or group outings. Through these pages, a customer pays a small amount to be added to a waitlist. This payment {{is-or-is-not}} refundable; its intended use is to ultimately be applied toward a future higher-value purchase. The payment turns a customer into a ‘warm lead’ for the {{client}} Sales team.

Mechanically, deposit (waitlist) pages are dummy series. A customer submitting their deposit payment is actually buying a ‘subscription’ to one of these ‘series’ – even though there are no subscriber tickets that will be fulfilled/visible to them after purchasing. The dummy series contains no linked events and no subscriber tickets are propagated onto buyers' accounts.
The typical flow/path from deposit/waitlist site to ultimate purchase is:

li.p: Customer buys the dummy subscription for the deposit/waitlist through the Ticket Packages tab of the {{client}} Performer page.

Ticket office management or reps process a return (manually or in bulk) of the subscriptions purchased for the deposit/waitlist dummy series, and reimburse the value to {{deposit-caption}} on the customers' CRM records.

When there is availability for the product the customer is on the waitlist to buy – such as a full {{subscription-caption}} or an event with an unoccupied suite or club area – a representative from the {{client}} ticket office reaches out to the customer to see if they want to convert their {{deposit-caption}} into a real purchase.
If the customer agrees, the representative applies the {{deposit-caption}} toward the larger purchase as one of the payment methods toward the final sale.

p.a: Deposit and Waitlist sites: Collecting deposits online to apply toward future purchases or enrollments
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SRN/pages/1767932400

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} host pages on SeatGeek where customers can put down deposits of varying amounts for future larger-value purchases, such as full {{subscription-caption}}s or group outings. Mechanically, deposit (waitlist) pages are dummy events. A customer submitting their deposit payment is actually buying a ‘ticket’ to one of these ‘events’ – even though there are no actual tickets that will be fulfilled/visible to them after purchasing. The ‘ticket’ to the dummy event that is purchased has its SG Online Ticket Management rules set to ensure that the ticket is not visible in the SeatGeek app or account manager to deposit buyers.
The typical flow/path from deposit/waitlist site to ultimate purchase is:

li.p: Customer buys the dummy event ticket for the deposit/waitlist. This {{may-or-will-be}} a hidden event that is purchasable on http://SeatGeek.com .

Ticket office management or reps process a return (manually or in bulk) of the tickets purchased for the deposit/waitlist dummy event, and reimburse the value to {{deposit-caption}} on the customers' CRM records.

When there is availability for the product the customer is on the waitlist to buy – such as a full {{subscription-caption}} or an event with an unoccupied suite or club area – a representative from the {{client}} ticket office reaches out to the customer to see if they want to convert their {{deposit-caption}} into a real purchase.
If the customer agrees, the representative applies the {{deposit-caption}} toward the larger purchase as one of the payment methods toward the final sale.

ac:rich-text-body.p: The {{client}} ticket office has a Group Sales team that handles both ticket sales and service requests for groups of {{group-size}} or more.

The {{client}} ticket office’s sales infrastructure, distribution relationships, rules implementation, and the manifest-layer management practices follow the recommended approaches for {{league-or-vertical}} organizations.

SeatGeek is the first-class distribution partner for both primary and secondary {{client}} ticket sales. The SG API security token can only sell inventory that has been explicitly allocated toward it; ‘open’ (unallocated, unlocked) inventory is not available for sale online on SeatGeek.
The {{client}} ticket office is responsible for allocating inventory that they wish to make publicly available for sale on SeatGeek.
