p.a: Unify Partner Integrations
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SGO/pages/1767997675
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/Seller/pages/4522541098

ac:rich-text-body.p: As an NFL team, {{client}} are required to distribute tickets through the NFL Ticket Exchange. Every NFL game – preseason, regular season, and postseason – that is built within Unify and mapped to the SeatGeek Open platform gets duly mapped to the NFL Ticket Exchange. {{client}} only integrate ‘main event’ tickets with the NFL Ticket Exchange, and do not integrate ancillary events (parking, premium events, or other non-game events) with that platform.

All tickets purchased as part of full {{subscriptions-caption}} must, when listed for resale, be listed simultaneously to both SeatGeek and onto the NFL Ticket Exchange. This simultaneous listing is done automatically when listing a ticket for resale through the SeatGeek app (My Tickets), or through the SeatGeek SDK.

When {{client}} {{STM-caption}}s list for resale through {{client}} Account Manager, their tickets are listed for resale only on the NFL Ticket Exchange, and are not automatically listed on SeatGeek. The {{STM-caption}}s will receive an email from SeatGeek after listing their ticket for resale by this method, suggesting that they additionally list the ticket for resale on SeatGeek as well, and providing a link to do so.
Any tickets listed for resale on SeatGeek and on the NFL Ticket Exchange can be delisted simultaneously from both platforms by the customer, from the SeatGeek My Tickets app.

h2: STANDARDGreen Sales Period, Return Period rules

ac:rich-text-body.p: Sales Period rules, from User reference guide: Events (Build)
{{client}} structure their Sales Period rules in the typical way, informed by three core practices:

td.p: Sales Period rules are usually set at the {{show-type-caption}} level, in order to be applied to as many {{league-or-vertical}} events as possible.
{{client}} will rarely override Sales Period rules at the {{show-caption}} or {{event-caption}} levels of the Sales Period rules hierarchy.
The most specific/niche rule scenarios will be highest-priority in the Sales Period rules set. Client type or coupon-driven presales generally will be highest-priority.
Broader/more general rules will be lower-priority. Public onsale dates for online sales will be conditioned to Security Token = SG API.

The final, lowest-priority rule in every Sales Period rule set for {{client}} will be unconditioned, and sets the latest possible date that a given {{event-caption}} is to be fully, globally on sale in all circumstances. This makes the Sales Period rules a complete rule set on every event.

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will have a ‘fallback’ Sales Period rule that exists at the Ticket product type level. This rule sets the Start Sales and Start Display date into the far-distant future unconditionally.

This rule only goes into effect when a given {{event-caption}} is built that has no Sales Period rules set upon it, there are no rules inherited from its parent {{show-caption}}, and there are no rules inherited from its grandparent {{show-type-caption}}.

Although it will be rare for this fallback rule to be evaluated without being superseded at a lower level, the rule has been set nonetheless in order to ensure that newly-built events without rules will be handled explicitly and appropriately.

The Return Period rules in effect on {{client}} products will be simpler. {{client}} set their Return Period rules at the Ticket and Subscription product type levels, without any overrides at lower levels within those product types' hierarchies. This ensures their return policies on single-events and {{subscription-caption}} packages are global to all products.
There will generally be two Return Period rules put in place:

li.p: Where Security Token IN [{{client}} Manager, SG FS], the Return Period on products is permitted up to 7 days post-{{event-caption}}. Exceptions can be made and additional rules can/will be added by the {{client}} management team for returns allowed even later than this.

In all other circumstances (no conditions), the Return Period on products is disallowed entirely; specifically, the rule is built to end the Return Period on a date in the distant past, which ensures that sales/service representatives or any other non-Superuser security tokens cannot directly process returns themselves. Sales reps and other ticket office users must speak with a manager at the {{client}} ticket office to grant a refund.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Returns of tickets may require that a Reason for Return be assigned to the transaction. See Extra Data rules for details.
Managing inventory (seat attributes), from User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages
{{client}} take the standard inventory management approaches for {{league-or-vertical}} organizations, making general use of locks, allocations, seat types, and custom properties.
Inventory management practices are designed with two overarching goals in mind:

li.p: Optimizing the balance of inventory that is sellable as single-{{event-caption}} tickets, versus as part of {{subscription-caption}} packages, in order to maximize revenue.
Minimizing the incidental creation of partially-available inventory, which complicates inventory management and may negatively impact sales.

p.a: Locks: Blocking off seats and GA capacity for specific uses
Allocations: Earmarking seats and GA areas for sales by specific sellers or customers

ac:rich-text-body.p: Managing inventory (seat attributes), from User reference guide: Series and Ticket Packages

{{client}} apply Locks and Allocations to seats within the manifest of their full {{subscription-caption}}. Setting these attributes at this manifest level allows those attributes to be propagated automatically onto the same seat locations within sub-series' and single-events' manifests. SeatGeek does not suggest applying those attributes at the {{hall-caption}} (Version) level, as attributes applied at that level are not propagated in any way onto the manifests of existing {{subscription-caption}} packages nor events.

As is customary for {{league-or-vertical}} organizations, {{client}} use Locks to generally restrict the selling of seats, while Allocations are used to generally permit the selling of seats by certain human or virtual Users.

The principal allocation used by {{client}} to make primary tickets available online for single-{{event-caption}} sales is {{open-allocation}} ({{open-allocation-acronym}}), though other allocations may be used as well. A full outlay of primary inventory that is available for sale online can be viewed by switching to the SG API user role while shopping for tickets in Unify Sales.

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [Entertainment]Purple Prime and VIP Locks and Allocations

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: [ENTERTAINMENT] Prime and VIP Locks and Allocations

p.a: Prime and VIP Locks and Allocations configurations
Amplify Prime Management - Configure Prime Allocation Type
VIP Packages - Configuring an Allocation for VIP Listings

ac:rich-text-body.p: While {{client}} will utilize the standard approach for general Locks and Allocations, additional inventory management items need to be configured for events that utilize Prime and VIP inventory.

li.p: All premium (Prime or VIP) inventory that is being sold online must be within a unique Allocation.
All other seats that are being held back from online sales need to be put into a Lock only, with no online-sellable allocation applied.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Prior to going on sale with an event, all Prime seats are to be put in both the Prime Lock and the Prime Allocation. While the seats are in this lock and allocation, the event’s Promoter will work through setting Seat Level Pricing on the seats; once that is done, they will then release (remove) the Prime lock. Once they release that lock, these seats will stay in the Prime allocation which makes the seats available to be sold online.

This approach is useful for Promoters when they are viewing Prime inventory in Amplify. They will utilize Amplify’s filtering to report on how well Opens, Prime and VIP inventory are selling. Because of this, we need to only display seats available for online sales when the Promoter is viewing these Amplify reports, by properly only allocating seats that are currently being sold online.

Any other seats that are being held, whether they are Artist inventory, Sponsor locations, internally-held seats, or any other inventory that is otherwise not being put on sale online must be within a designated lock, and no online-sellable allocation.

p.a: Amplify Prime Management: Setting seat level pricing for Prime inventory

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will receive training on Unify (SRO)'s Seat-Level Pricing feature, which allows the price of a seat to be overridden and specified on the seat itself in lieu of the Price defined within the Price List.

{{client}} may utilize this feature for third-party events such as concerts, if and when it is requested by those events' Promoters; it is not expected to be utilized for regular {{league-or-vertical}} events.

p.a: Amplify Prime Management: Setting seat level pricing for Prime inventory
SeatGeekIQ (SGIQ): Maximizing the value of your inventory

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will receive training on Unify (SRO)'s Seat-Level Pricing feature, which allows the price of a seat to be overridden and specified on the seat itself, which bypasses the Price defined within the Price List when sold at specified price types.
{{client}} may utilize this feature for third-party events such as concerts, if and when it is requested by those events' Promoters.

Although {{client}} do not generally expect to manually apply seat-level pricing toward seats at their regular {{league-or-vertical}} {{event-caption}}s within Unify Sales, SeatGeekIQ leverages seat-level pricing. As a result, seat-level pricing {{may-or-will}} be activated on {{some-or-all}} {{league-or-vertical}} {{event-caption}}s.

p.a: Unmanifested Seats configurations
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/browse/MAP-9243

ac:rich-text-body.p: Unmanifested Seats (also referred to as Private Property, or Unmans) are utilized by most venues for entertainment events when promoters are involved. Unmanifested Seats are seats that the venue keeps for themselves to sell so that the venue keeps any revenue associated with the sale of those seats, rather than sharing the revenue with the event promoter. How and why the arrangement of which seat locations are considered to be unmanifested inventory exists, and who is aware of it, can depend on the venue & the event’s promoter.

These Unmanifested Seats should not be reflected in any promoter-facing reporting or in Amplify Heatmaps due to the nature of this inventory being physically available to sell in the venue, but are not considered to be a part of the venue rental by promoters. Typically arena clients will sell unmanifested seats directly to fans through Box Office sales or will distribute these unmanifested seat locations to client Broker partners. Unmanifested inventory cannot be sold on SeatGeek and must be sold off platform.

When building an entertainment event in Unify, all Unmanifested inventory should be built into the venue map being used for the main event. These seat locations should not live in a separate venue map or on a separate event outside of the main event.

On the venue map being used for the main event, within the venue design Seat Attributes management, the Unmanifested seats should be marked as Private Property. A Lock Type should be created for and added to Unmanifested seats, utilizing the Locked for all (excluded from reported capacity) setting set to TRUE. As Unmanifested seats should not be counted among your available seats, this will ensure that seats carrying this Lock do not count towards your available inventory in reporting as well as analytics views in Amplify.

Being that Unmanifested seat locations are not reflected in any promoter-facing manifests, the SeatGeek mapping team will need to create entertainment event maps where the Unmanifested locations do not appear on the SeatGeek ISMs (interactive seat maps). This will also carry the masked seat map into Amplify, suppressing the Unmanifested seats from Promoter’s view.

p.a: Extra Data Forms and Rules: Collecting additional customer or transaction information

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} make limited use of Extra Data rules.
Their most commonly-activated extra data rule will be the Reason for Return form, which must be submitted for all returns that are not exchanges or reprices.

p.a: Sale Modes

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} use the predefined, stock Sale Modes provisioned by the SeatGeek team. Those predefined Sale Modes are:

td.p: Online sales, only used by the SG API or other integrated distribution partners.
Sales or reservations processed via bulk operations.
Sales performed by box office agents at {{primary-venue}} on {{event-caption}} days.
This sale mode requires that a customer be identified; every transaction is trackable and associated with a CRM record.

A generic sale mode for transactions processed by {{client}} ticket office users outside the context of walkup sales (Over the Counter) or bulk operations (Batch Sales); this sale mode is used for the majority of all sales.
This sale mode requires that a customer be identified; every transaction is trackable and associated with a CRM record.

p.a: Sale Points: Associating workstations with sale points for selling and printing

ac:rich-text-body.p: Printer (Dispatch) rules, from User reference guide: Printing

{{client}} have Sale Points defined for physical (box office windows, reps' and managers' computers in the ticket office) workstations and virtual sellers (SG API, SYSTEM, and those for distribution partners.)
Sale Points' Printer Dispatcher rules are all configured to route print jobs to virtual system printers in the typical way:

li.p: Barcoded document types such as (Subscriber’s) Ticket are dispatched to the Simulator Printer.
Receipt-typed and informational document types such as Confirmation Letter document types are dispatched to the Email Documents printer.

PDF-formatted document types such as (Subscriber’s) PAH Ticket are dispatched either to the system PDF Documents printer, or to a locally-installed PDF Documents-typed printer, which saves the printed file to a folder on a particular workstation.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Individual users at the {{client}} ticket office who have other, unique print routing needs – such as thermal ticket printers – may add additional Printer Dispatcher rules within their personal sale point(s).
Sites, from Sale Points: Associating workstations with sale points for selling and printing

{{client}} have multiple Sites defined in their environment, to which sale points are assigned in order to denote either their physical locations (including their time zone), or the nature of how a sale was processed.
Of the four predefined Sites, three represent virtual (non-local) media:

td.p: The only predefined Site that represents a physical location. In the case of the {{client}} ticket office, the personal sale points for all human users within the ticket office as well as box office window sellers are assigned to this Site.
A virtual, non-local Site to which all non-human sellers' sale points are assigned. This includes SeatGeek online (the SG API sale point), and any distribution partners.
A semi-local Site to which human SeatGeek users' sale points – such as those for the SeatGeek FS team, Client Services, or others – are assigned.
A virtual, non-local Site to which the default, generic SYSTEM sale point is assigned. Neither virtual nor human users' sale points should be assigned to this Site.

h1: Venues, Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [all] Venues, Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Overview; 1 of 5]

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: [ALL] Venues, Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Overview; 1 of 5]

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} have multiple Venues, {{hall-caption}}s and {{hall-caption}} Versions built jointly by their ticket ops team and the SeatGeek Implementations team.

Including their primary {{hall-caption}} of {{primary-venue}}, {{client}} have defined multiple Venues (physical locations) in their Unify (SRO) environment. Within their defined Venue locations, {{client}} have built multiple {{hall-caption}}s. Each {{hall-caption}} may have multiple {{hall-caption}} Versions defined within it.
Details of the {{hall-caption}}s defined for {{primary-venue}} are as follows:

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [all] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Stands; 2 of 5]

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: [ALL] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Stands; 2 of 5]

ac:rich-text-body.p: Creating a Stand, from User reference guide: Venues and Halls
Adding a Stand, from User reference guide: Venues and Halls

Within each {{hall-caption}}, one or more Stands can be defined. Stands are created within the editing screen of a given {{hall-caption}}, and are always enabled for Access Control. Areas are later assigned to a Stand.

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [all] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Areas and Sections; 3 of 5]

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: [ALL] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Areas and sections; 3 of 5]

ac:rich-text-body.p: Areas, from User reference guide: Venues and Halls
Sectors, from User reference guide: Venues and Halls

a.u: Seat Perks: Extras and special conditions for seat listings

ac:rich-text-body.p: Each {{hall-caption}} in the {{client}} system will have all of its manifested Sections defined with a one-to-one ratio to their parent Areas; no Area will consist of more than one Section. This allows for maximal granularity of rules and policies to be defined on a Section-by-Section basis, as some rules engines only support Area-level value getters.

{{client}} ticket listings sold on SeatGeek’s site and apps will also carry Seat Perks. Seat Perks are an optional, fan-facing addition to the SeatGeek sale flow that can be configured by SeatGeek, according to the {{client}} ticket office’s specifications.

The Area description (External Reference) property is a free text field that can be set upon any Area. Historically, this property was used to display Seller Notes within SeatGeek online sale flows. Seller notes might contain information about benefits and/or policies that apply to all seats within a given Area. With the introduction of the Seat Perks model, the Area description (External Reference) property is generally no longer utilized.

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [all] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [General Admission; 4 of 5]

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: [ALL] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [General Admission; 4 of 5]

ac:rich-text-body.p: 'Fake GA', from SeatGeek event page: Seated, General Admission, and Best Available

{{client}} have adopted the standard general admission approach for organizations selling and distributing tickets on SeatGeek Open, utilizing ‘Fake GA’ areas in lieu of native, ‘true’ General Admission areas. Fake GA areas are technically built as reserved-seating areas within the manifest, with assigned seats; row and seat information are hidden from customer-facing sale flows and ticket management interfaces. Among Fake GA’s multiple advantages, it allows custom ticket-specific information (banners, entry gate information) to be displayed on mobile tickets in the SeatGeek app for {{client}} customers.
{{client}} have not and will not build any seatless ‘True GA’ areas without first consulting with SeatGeek.

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [Fortress]Yellow [all] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Gates and Turnstiles (Fortress); 5 of 5

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: [ALL] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Gates and Turnstiles (Fortress); 5 of 5]

ac:rich-text-body.p: Configuration requirements within Unify (SRO), from Fortress Access Control

{{client}} have Turnstiles defined within their {{primary-venue}} {{hall-caption}}, in order to designate for their Fortress Access Control connection which tickets (by Area) are scannable at exterior entrances, versus which are scannable only at interior locations. Interior (also called secondary) scanning is conducted for entry to Premium sections, and is enabled through assigning Areas to the Premium turnstile.

All other tickets which are scannable for entry only at exterior entrances – requiring no interior/secondary scanning in order to be permitted for entry to their seats/section – will have their Areas associated with the All turnstile. The turnstile is arbitrarily named All as a matter of convention; it is simply a designation of non-Premium areas, which can be accessed by the conventional entry-scanning method at the exterior entrances to {{primary-venue}}.

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [SRO AC]Yellow [all] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Gates and Turnstiles (SRO Built-In Access Control); 5 of 5]

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: [ALL] Halls (Venue Maps), Hall (Venue Map) Versions [Gates and Turnstiles (SRO Built-In Access Control); 5 of 5]

ac:rich-text-body.p: Gates and Turnstiles, from User reference guide: SRO Built-In Access Control

{{client}} have Gates and Turnstiles defined within their {{primary-venue}} {{hall-caption}} in order to designate which tickets (by Area) and/or ticket owners (by Client Type) are scannable for entry through particular entrances.

Gates are defined to control entry via from the outside of {{primary-venue}}, while Turnstiles are defined to control entry to internal, limited-access parts of the {{hall-caption}}, such as premium sections.

p.a: Seat Types: Marking seats as ADA-accessible or obstructed view

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} use Seat Types principally to mark certain seat locations as accessible (and/or ADA companion). {{primary-venue}} has dedicated sections for ADA seating, which {{client}} sell online, through the back office, and accommodate exchanges (relocations) into for customers with accessibility needs.

Another common usage of Seat Types is to designate seating as having an obstructed or limited view. {{primary-venue}} {{obv-does-or-does-not}} have limited view seats, and as a result the {{client}} ticket office {{obv-does-or-does-not}} utilize the Obstructed View class of seat type.

Seat Types can optionally have Seat Alert text assigned to them, such that custom, seat-specific language can be shown within listings on SeatGeek, as well as at the bottom fulfilled mobile ticket through a banner-style message. {{client}} {{seat-alert-do-or-do-not}} add Seat Alerts to their Seat Types.

Additionally, Acknowledgments (terms and conditions) can be related to specific seats and listings that a customer buys or receives via transfer on the SeatGeek platform, with the specific Acknowledgement language activated according to a seat’s assigned Seat Type.
All seat types are applied to seats within the master {{hall-caption}} Version that {{client}} have assigned to their {{events-caption}} and {{subscriptions-caption}}.
Customizing features through Rally, from User reference guide: Venues and Halls

{{client}} use {{some-or-all}} of the Custom Property fields that exist on a seat level to present additional verbiage on mobile tickets to ticket owners within the SeatGeek app, such as suggested entry gates, hospitality benefits, or other helpful information.
These fields and their specific usages/purposes are as follows:

p.code: Access to Club Lounge via elevator at north end of concourse.

td.p: Second line of top banner of ticket, underneath the Club Access value

ac:rich-text-body.p: This value will only be displayed in the top banner of the ticket if the Club Access field retrieves any value at all. If Club Access has a null value, the banner atop the mobile ticket will not appear at all, regardless of whether a Secondary Club Access value exists.

p.code: Outside food and beverage is not permitted in the Club Lounge.

td.p: Middle of ticket, beneath barcode and above seat location
Middle of ticket, between Entry Gate value (if present) and seat location

ac:rich-text-body.p: These Custom Property values will be set within the master {{hall-caption}} Version assigned to events at {{primary-venue}} and {{series-caption}} packages. Custom Properties set at the {{hall-caption}} Version level are automatically inherited and reflected in all product-level manifests that utilize that {{hall-caption}} Version. {{client}} will rarely or never set or change Custom Property values within the manifests of specific events or {{subscription-caption}} packages.
The {{client}} pricing approach follows the standard for {{league-or-vertical}} organizations.
Price Lists, from User reference guide: Pricing
Price Lists will be built by the {{client}} ticket office management team.
They will employ typical price list build and management practices:

li.p: Ticket-level price lists will be built for both Regular and Subscriber tickets, for use in single-{{event-caption}} ticket sales and {{subscription-caption}}s that use event-based pricing.
Subscription-level price lists will be built for {{subscription-caption}}s that use series-based pricing.

The % and $ discounting functions will be used at times within price lists to drop prices for non-leading price types relative to the leading price type. This is most commonly done for comp tickets, which are benchmarked to a 100% discount relative to the leading price type.
Price Type Availability rules are used within almost every {{event-caption}}, as well as most {{subscription-caption}}s.

There will almost always be at least two distinct price lists put into effect for each event: the Regular Event Tickets Price List for single-{{event-caption}} pricing, and the Subscriber Ticket Price List for the event’s revenue share within a particular {{subscription-caption}} package.

h3: StandardGreen Prime and VIP Price Types to Allocations

ac:rich-text-body.h5: [Entertainment]Yellow Prime and VIP Price Types to Allocations

ac:structured-macro.ac:parameter: Prime and VIP Price Type to Allocations

p.a: Price Type to Allocations
Amplify Prime Management - Prime Price Type to Allocation
Prime and VIP Price Levels and Price Types configurations

ac:rich-text-body.p: Base Prices, from User reference guide: Pricing
Potential Income Calculation, from User reference guide: Pricing

For {{client}} entertainment events, the standard practice of configuring Price Types is utilized, though there are specific Price Types needed in order to appropriately price Prime and VIP inventory. These events will utilize the Price Type to Allocation linkage system for all Prime and VIP inventory. Many Price Types with unique Prices will be found within a single Price Level on a Price List.

For any event in which Prime or VIP inventory is sold, Base Prices must be entered within the event’s main Price List. Base prices, also sometimes referred to as tickets' Face Value, are used to calculate the 'Lift' (which represents extra revenue earned by the ticket office) upon Prime and VIP ticket sales.
A Potential Income Price List must also be applied to the Event.
Price Type Availability rules, from User reference guide: Pricing
{{client}} build their Price Type Availability rules in the typical way for an organization selling on SeatGeek.

Their price list’s leading price type, which is customarily {{default-leading-pt}}, will in most cases be the only price type availed for online sales of single-{{event-caption}} tickets. This rule is conditioned to Security Token = SG API. Exceptions may be made where SeatGeekIQ-related, and VIP or Prime price types may also be availed within the same rule.
Additional rules may avail unique price types to specific sellers (per their Security Tokens, usually), or to specific buyers (per their Client Types, for example).

Price Type Availability rules are customarily set at the {{show-type-caption}} level, then inherited down to the individual {{events-caption}}. For {{subscriptions-caption}}, Price Type Availability rules are usually set at either the {{series-caption}} or {{series-template-caption}} levels within the Subscription product type hierarchy.

Any {{event-caption}} that is included (or selectable) within a {{subscription-caption}} with event-based pricing in effect must also have one or more Price Type Availability rules set to avail the price type(s) at which a {{subscription-caption}} can be purchased.
Price Type Availability rules, from User reference guide: Pricing

{{client}} build their Price Type Availability rules in the typical way for a USL team selling on SeatGeek. They make use of two price types that are selectively and mutually-exclusively availed based on whether the customer is purchasing the ticket on the day of the {{event-caption}}, or in advance of the {{event-caption}} day:

td.p: {{client}} avail the {{advance-pt}} price type to early buyers, up to {{advance-hours-days}} prior to the {{event-caption}} start time.
{{advance-pt}} will usually be the only price type availed for early/advance online sales of single-{{event-caption}} tickets, with the possible exception of any SeatGeekIQ-related price types.
This rule is conditioned to apply to the Security Token = SG API, combined with a time-based condition of either {{advance-hours-days}} Hours before Event, or based on a fixed Current Date/Time.
Once within {{advance-hours-days}} of the {{event-caption}}, {{client}} avail the {{event-day-pt}} price type to buyers.
{{event-day-pt}} will usually be the only price type availed once it is in effect, with the possible exception of any SeatGeekIQ-related price types.
This rule is conditioned to apply to the Security Token = SG API, combined with a time-based condition of either {{advance-hours-days}} Hours before Event, or based on a fixed Current Date/Time.

ac:rich-text-body.p: This pricing mechanic serves the purpose of giving the {{client}} ticket office the ability to shift pricing in response to supply and demand levels as the {{event-caption}} approaches.
Additional rules may avail unique price types to specific sellers (per their Security Tokens, usually), or to specific buyers (per their Client Types, for example).

Price Type Availability rules are customarily set at the {{show-type-caption}} level, then inherited down to the individual {{events-caption}}. For a {{subscription-caption}}, Price Type Availability rules are usually set at either the {{series-caption}} or {{series-template-caption}} levels within the Subscription product type hierarchy.

Any {{event-caption}} that is included (or selectable) within a {{subscription-caption}} with event-based pricing in effect must also have one or more Price Type Availability rules set to avail the price type(s) at which a {{subscription-caption}} can be purchased.

p.a: SeatGeekIQ (SGIQ): Maximizing the value of your inventory

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} have incorporated some of SeatGeek’s solutions for market-based pricing, sometimes referred to as variable pricing.

Market conditions are monitored by {{client}} ticket office management, and management directly updates pricing within events' Price Lists accordingly in order to maintain competitive and comparable price points between their primary and secondary markets. These Price List changes may be made manually within the Price List editing grid, or using the Bulk Update Price List feature, depending on the breadth of the pricing adjustments.

p.a: SeatGeekIQ PriceIQ: Pricing primary inventory using allocations
SeatGeekIQ (SGIQ): Maximizing the value of your inventory

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} utilize SeatGeek’s PriceIQ platform as part of their market-based pricing approach. {{client}} provides SeatGeek with a pre-allotted inventory position – an amount of seats that share a lock and allocation that is unique to the given PriceIQ deal term. This allotment may be made within one or multiple {{events-caption}} for a given deal term.

SeatGeek’s pricing system continually evaluates market conditions to find the optimal price for the allotted inventory, as well as the right number of seats within the allotment to make available for sale on the SeatGeek event page at a given time. Tickets sold through PriceIQ will have a unique price type for ease of reporting.

Managers and sales reps in the {{client}} ticket office are allowed to sell through PriceIQ-allocated inventory, if desired. Contact SeatGeek to learn more about configuring your SeatGeekIQ inventory for sale both online and through the back office simultaneously.

p.a: SeatGeekIQ (SGIQ): Maximizing the value of your inventory

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} participate in SeatGeek’s ReachIQ program, which broadcasts unsold, primary inventory from Unify to secondary ticketing markets beyond the SeatGeek site. With ReachIQ, {{client}} provides SeatGeek with an inventory allotment through a shared lock and allocation that is unique to ReachIQ. This lock and allocation are not the same lock and allocation used for PriceIQ deal terms. This allotment may be made within one or multiple {{events-caption}} for a given deal term.

SeatGeek’s pricing system continually evaluates market conditions to find the optimal ‘broadcast price’ for the allotted inventory, as well as the right number of seats within the allotment to make available for sale on external, third-party secondary markets at a given time. Tickets sold through ReachIQ will have a unique price type for ease of reporting.
ReachIQ-allocated inventory is not allowed to be sold by back office users.

p.a: Fees (Commissions): Item, transaction, and others

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} make use of each of the major categories of fees – item fees, inside-fees, and transaction fees – upon their sales, as well as the SeatGeek-shared versions of each of those fee categories.
They also make make some use of ‘inside-out’ fees, which are regular item Fees (rather than Inside-Fees) that are defined with The price displayed in the basket includes this fee set to enabled.

{{client}} generally treat most or all of their fees as refundable, as defined within either the fee’s Return Policy (for item fees and inside-fees) or the product’s Return Transaction Fee Rules. The refundability of these fees is set so that the default reimbursement for unsatisfied or escalated customers, in normal circumstances, comes to a full refund. Unless otherwise stipulated by the {{client}} ticket office, returns or exchanges of products will usually credit (refund) assessed fees to the customer.

The configuration of fees on {{client}} products may be subject to the SeatGeek Fee Audit. The specific details of which fees are subject to audit, and what their terms are, are detailed in the following document:

p.a: Fees (Commissions): Item, transaction, and others

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} make use of each of the major categories of fees – item fees, inside-fees, and transaction fees – upon their sales, as well as the SeatGeek-shared versions of each of those fee categories.
They also make make some use of ‘inside-out’ fees, which are regular item Fees (rather than Inside-Fees) that are defined with The price displayed in the basket includes this fee set to enabled.

{{client}} generally treat most or all of their fees as refundable, as defined within either the fee’s Return Policy (for item fees and inside-fees) or the product’s Return Transaction Fee Rules. The refundability of these fees is set so that the default reimbursement for unsatisfied or escalated customers, in normal circumstances, comes to a full refund. Unless otherwise stipulated by the {{client}} ticket office, returns or exchanges of products will usually credit (refund) assessed fees to the customer.

When a {{subscriber-caption}} resells a ticket on the NFL Ticket Exchange, they incur no seller fee when the ticket sells. Any tickets that are not listed on the NFL Ticket Exchange and are instead sold directly on the SeatGeek Open Marketplace will incur a {{seller-fee-percentage}} fee.

The configuration of fees on {{client}} products may be subject to the SeatGeek Fee Audit. The specific details of which fees are subject to audit, and what their terms are, are detailed in {{fee-audit-SoT-url}}.

p.a: Entertainment Fee Builds and Configurations

ac:rich-text-body.p: When setting up fees for Entertainment events, fee structures, such as using fee bands, and how the fees are configured within Unify can vary from how a standard event is built.

A fee band is a price range condition set on an Item Fee rule that will be applied to a ticket only if the ticket price falls within the price range defined within the fee rule, in addition to other fee rule conditions that are put in place when building out the entertainment event.

Fee bands are typically consistent in price across most entertainment events at a venue, contractually defined by the agreed upon fee structure. Because these fees tend to be the same for most entertainment events, all fee band rules should be set on the Template Type level for the clients defined Entertainment template type.

Fee bands should be configured on the Template Type once, and should not require them to be reconfigured in the future. Since these fees are defined by the contractual agreement between SeatGeek and the client, these fees should be configured during the implementation and do not need to be managed individually for each event build.
Setting these fee band rules on the Template Type will allow for the defined fees to carry down to any event that is built using the Entertainment Template Type.
When configuring fee bands, it is important to properly define the item list price range to account for every possible dollar amount, down to the cent, that could be spent on a ticket.
For example:
If there are two separate fee bands defined, one for tickets under $100 and one for tickets over $100.

p.em: Do not set one fee band rule that only consists of a price range of < $100.00, with the second price range rule set at > $100.01. This would lead to fees not being applied to a ticket that is exactly $100.00 in price.

p.strong: Do set the fee band rules with one rule set at the Item list price BETWEEN $0.01 and $100.00, and the second fee band rule set BETWEEN $100.01 and the maximum potential value of a ticket.
This will ensure that all prices of a ticket will properly associate the correct fee band when carting a ticket.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Inside fees, such as the SG Prime Ticket fee should also be set on the Template Type level, including all of the associated Prime Price Types. If there is an event that is exempt from the Prime Management fee, an Event NOT IN rule should be added to the Template Type level. More information on the Prime Management fee can be found here.
If an event requires a unique fee band association, these Item Fee rules should be set on the Event level, overriding the default fee band rules on the Template Type.

When setting Item Fee rules on the Event level, it is important to ensure that all item fees are being accounted for when overriding the Template Level rules. The Event level rules should include any and all associated fees; credit card fees, facility fees, taxes etc, even if they do not differ from the rules that were in place on the Template Type level. By copying the Template Type rule down to the Event level, and then adjusting the unique fees on the event level only, this will assist in ensuring that all fees are still being accounted for.

If the fee band rules differ based on the event type, such as an entertainment concert vs. a Feld Family Show (ex. Disney on Ice), a separate Temple Type should be created for each event category, which can have its own fee bands defined on the Template Type.

While most fees should be set on the Template Type, or the Event level if they are uniquely different from the defined Template Type fee configurations, there are specific fees that should always be set on the Global Item Fee level. These Global Level fees need to be included for every event, on top of the Template Type fees, or Event level if necessary.

Promoter Fees, often referred to as the Promoter Bump, should always be set at the Global level via the Product Default Rules. Another fee that is frequently used by come clients is a Charity Bump, which is similar to a Promoter Bump, which should be set on the Global level as well.

The Promoter Bump fee rules should be built out on the Global Item Fee level, using the Event IN condition to define which events the fee should be applied to. This should always be set on the Global level to ensure that the Promoter fee will always flow down to all events, although using defined Event IN conditions, alleviating the chance of missing or misconfiguring these fee for any and all entertainment events.

{{client}} assess Taxes as an additional item-level price modifier, alongside conventional (Fee-typed) item-level and transaction-level price modifiers. In some cases, they may also assess Taxes upon specific Fees, imposed within the Fee’s definition.
{{client}} do not make use of VATs ('Value-Added Taxes').
{{client}} do not impose any Global Transaction Fees at the Basket level, as this type of fee can cause fulfillment failures in secondary markets such SeatGeek’s broker-driven Sellerdirect platform.

p.a: Coupons: Creating promo and access codes for online and back office sales

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} build Coupons, also known as Promo Codes or Access Codes, in order to:

li.p: Grant early (presale) access to ticket buyers.
Offer customers tickets at lesser/discounted price points relative to the standard face-value price.
Let customers unlock otherwise unavailable listings that are exclusively purchasable through the coupon.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Some coupons will serve multiple (or all) of these purposes at once.

In general, the majority of coupons built by {{client}} will use randomly-generated, unique Coupon IDs. This is SeatGeek’s recommended approach to all {{league-or-vertical}} organizations, as it naturally prevents coupon code abuse or contagion through repeated redemptions. In cases where a coupon code dramatically reduces a ticket’s price, or that unlocks exclusive, valuable listings, it’s strongly urged to generate and distribute these random and unique Coupon IDs.

In rarer cases, {{client}} may build coupons that are identified by ‘A Name’; this means the code that the customer inputs to redeem the coupon is the same for everyone and is not unique in any way. This is generally only done for coupons that convey minor/trivial benefits or that are only redeemable for a very limited time. These are cases where promo code ‘virality’ – in the form of resharing of the code on social media, for example – is either not a concern, or would actually be a positive thing.

Wherever possible, coupons will be built as ‘left-side’ coupons, which do not use a special price type flip, and instead are only set to Sell only at ... a special ~ price type. This type of build is preferred, as immediately upon being applied as an Access code on the SeatGeek event page, it displays the exact price per ticket that the customer will pay.

In some cases, such as buy-one-get-one or other ratio-based deals, {{client}} will build ‘both-sides’ coupons that will Sell only at ... their regular, default, face-value price type in their price list, but that also flips some tickets in the basket to a distinct special ~ price type. This type of coupon configuration is sometimes necessary but not generally favored, because the price per ticket displayed to the user will be priced according to the ‘pre-flip’ ticket’s price type, and not the post-flip special ~ price type’s price.
{{client}} do not make use of Discounts nor Special Price Lists if and when they define Coupon Benefits.

The duplicate coupons feature flag (internal - seatgeek only) for the {{client}} SeatGeek Performer page is {{enabled-or-disabled}}. {{client}} understand that enabling the duplicate coupons feature precludes the use of Bundles online.
{{client}} ticket office staff to exchange tickets that were bought using coupons by processing ‘manual exchanges’:

li.p: Select the ticket and begin the conventional Return flow.

Before completing the return, while still on the Payment screen (where the Reimbursement methods are listed), click into the {{event-caption}}s tab and add the new, target seat(s) to the basket. These are the seats into which the customer is being exchanged.

Click Next to proceed to the Payment screen and reimburse (or pay) off the residual basket balance; if this is an even exchange in which the vacated ticket and the target ticket are of equal value, Finish the transaction.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Completing this ‘manual exchange’ will return/cancel the original ticket bought with the coupon and, within the same transaction, sell a new ticket onto the account to replace it.

The Packages feature is not yet generally documented in the SeatGeek Knowledge Center. For now, https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/11VYtIRZwH664ZlPGj0tYYOdIBSb9skSD/edit#slide=id.p6 serves as SeatGeek’s most authoritative documentation on Packages.

{{client}} in some rare cases may utilize the native Packages functionality in Unify (SRO), for cases where they wish to convey a benefit or discount to buyers without providing them with (nor forcing them to redeem) a coupon code.
Like coupons, the Packages that {{client}} build will utilize special ~ price type flips, converting some or all tickets in the basket to a special price type when the Package’s conditions are met.
{{client}} do not make use of Discounts nor Special Price Lists when defining Package Benefits.
The Bundles (SGO) feature is not yet generally documented in the SeatGeek Knowledge Center.
internal - seatgeek only Bundles (SGO) serves as SeatGeek’s internal documentation on Bundles.

{{client}} in some rare cases may utilize the native Packages functionality in Unify (SRO) to configure an SGO Bundle, for cases where they wish to bundle a combination of single-game tickets and other event tickets, vouchers, or merchandise items that can be sold online.
Like coupons, the Packages that {{client}} build will utilize special ~ price type flips, converting some or all tickets in the basket to a special price type when the Bundle’s conditions are met.
{{client}} do not make use of Discounts nor Special Price Lists when defining Package Benefits.
In order to sell bundles, the {{client}} domain cannot utilize duplicate coupons. If {{client}} is using bundles, then they have chosen not to use duplicate coupons.

p.a: Prompts: Upsells and additional messaging in the customer's basket

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will sometimes offer upsells to customers making purchases on SeatGeek, by way of Unify (SRO) Prompts.
Their most common upsells are Parking passes for single-{{event-caption}} and {{subscription-caption}} purchases.

{{client}} use the Unify (SRO) CRM module in the typical way for an organization selling on SeatGeek Open. The Unify (SRO) CRM houses all SeatGeek-ticketed events' ticket sales and ownership information.
CRM: The Customer Relationship Management module, from User reference guide: Sales and CRM (Unify)
{{client}} create and manage all records within the Unify (SRO) CRM as Customer-typed records.
They do not create nor utilize Account-typed records, even for corporate partners or other CRM records representing collectives or conglomerates rather than individuals.
Profile: Classification tab, from User reference guide: Sales and CRM (Unify)
{{client}} make extensive use of Client Types within their CRM database. Client Types serve several purposes in their ticketing operations, including:

li.p: 'Tagging’ accounts with client types for quick and easy searching and identification within the CRM database.
Conditionally revealing Rally widgets in the SeatGeek app to specific customers.
Triggering rules for sales, pricing, SG Online Ticket Management, and other policies.
Filtering reports to only return data related to a subset of CRM records.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Almost all client types will be created and named by the {{client}} ticket office, with the exception of some that were created by SeatGeek:

The following client types should not be renamed or reconfigured in any way; their names within the {{client}} Unify (SRO) environment must be labeled as follows in order to have their stated effects.

td.p: When applied, Invoices generated for a CRM record are not displayed in the Invoices section of the SeatGeek Account Manager Payment tab. The visibility of Draft Invoices generated for a CRM record will not be affected by this client type.

ac:rich-text-body.p: This client type is rarely used, as {{client}} generally will only be generating Draft Invoices as opposed to traditional Invoices.

td.p: When applied, any payment plans that the customer is or was enrolled in will have their installments' dates and amounts hidden.

The customer can still view the overall state of their payment plan including how much has been paid and how much is left to pay, as well as how many installments (both paid and pending) their plan consists of, and what payment method would be charged for future installments.
When applied, the SeatGeek Account Manager Payment tab is hidden entirely from the customer.

When applied, the History panel at the bottom of the SeatGeek Account Manager Payment tab – where their history of purchases and payments is displayed, and where receipts for those historic purchases may be downloaded – is hidden from the customer.

A pre-built client type that, by convention, is meant to block all ticket management capabilities from a customer with the exception of Ticket Visibility; a customer carrying this client type may still be able to see their event ticket in the SeatGeek app, but cannot transfer or re-sell it, nor view its barcode or download it as a PDF.

ac:rich-text-body.p: The Deny AM client type only has these effects if they are specified in the event's effective SG Online Ticket Management rules; if {{client}} does not set any rules that are conditioned upon this client type, it will not have any effect of its own. This client type has no intrinsic effect or purpose of its own.

td.p: A general-purpose client type that is usually applied to SeatGeek employees' CRM records, rather than {{client}} ticket office employees', in order to internally test functionality.

The Staff Tester client type may, in some cases, be applied to {{client}} ticket office employees' CRM records to grant them testing capabilities similar to SeatGeek personnel’s, but for the most part this system-generated client type will normally be applied to only SeatGeek employees' CRMs.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Profile: Remarks, from User reference guide: Sales and CRM (Unify)
{{client}} allow representatives to apply Remarks to CRM records as a way to alert other back office users of critical information about a customer or account.

While the majority of service-level information about customers for representatives to reference (dietary restrictions, personality traits, history with organization, etc.) is housed outside of the Unify (SRO) CRM in the {{client}} organization’s auxiliary {{external-third-party-CRM}} instance, some of the more vital information will be stored as Remarks, which will be triggered as Alerts to be automatically surfaced whenever a given CRM record is opened or is being sold-to.

p.a: Sales and Service Representatives: Assigning reps to customers and transactions

ac:rich-text-body.p: For every representative that works within the {{client}} ticket office, there will be both a Sales Representative and Service Representative set up within the Unify (SRO) CRM in their name.

li.p: The Sales Representative record for a rep is credited with sales, such as renewals, single-{{event-caption}} or group sales, or coupon redemptions. Sales representatives will be assigned at both the item level and the CRM level.

The Service Representative record for a rep is associated directly with customers' CRM records in order to surface their contact information an a picture/avatar of them within SeatGeek Account Manager, shown to customers paying via Account Manager Checkout.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Customarily, every rep will also have a third CRM record that is not associated with a Sales nor a Service Representative record at all, and instead will be set up as a regular, standalone CRM record. It is this CRM record to which a rep’s own personal SeatGeek account is linked, allowing reps to manage their own tickets within the SeatGeek app.

The {{client}} ticket office's analytics department will at times report on the Representative (item) for sales of major products, and use this data viewed within Unify directly or within a third-party system such as {{external-dwh}} to calculate commission payouts to reps.

p.a: Correspondence Processes: Sending outbound emails from SRO

ac:rich-text-body.p: In order to send emails out of Unify (SRO), such as purchase confirmations, print-at-home tickets and other custom-branded documents, SeatGeek uses Mandrill (MailChimp). {{client}} use the predefined Correspondence Processes and Communication Profiles built into Unify (SRO) containing SeatGeek’s Mandrill (Mailchimp) credentials and connection information.

The reply-to address for emails sent out of Unify (SRO) is an address within {{client}} corporate internet domain, {{client-internet-domain}}. Accordingly, the {{client}} IT department are responsible for adding and maintaining Mandrill (Mailchimp) as an authorized outbound (SMTP) server in their domain’s SPF/DKIM records.

p.a: Delivery Methods

ac:rich-text-body.p: A Delivery Method can optionally be assigned to a transaction, usually for the purposes of sending a physical ticket or other document to the buyer, or for charging an additional amount for the shipping costs of tickets or merchandise.

As an organization operating on the SeatGeek Open platform, with a mobile-{{only-or-first-or-}} fulfillment approach, {{client}} {{do-or-do-not}} usually set delivery method availability rules on their products, and {{do-or-do-not}} set extra data rules that would require the selection of a delivery method in the purchasing process.

p.a: Client Duplication: Identifying unidentified clients as existing clients

ac:rich-text-body.p: In Unify (SRO), Client Duplication rules are used to prevent the creation (whether accidental or nefarious) of multiple CRM records to the same individual, registered under similar or identical identifying information.

Client Duplication rules within the {{client}} CRM follow SeatGeek’s recommended approach for all organizations operating on the SeatGeek Open platform; the primary attribute that cannot be shared between multiple CRMs is Email address, which in most or all cases must be unique and used by only one CRM record.
Creating or editing a CRM record, from User reference guide: Sales and CRM (Unify)

p.a: Extra Data Forms and Rules: Collecting additional customer or transaction information

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} may make use of Client Extra Data fields to store supplementary personal information on CRM records. These Extra Data fields will be custom-captioned according to their purpose, and any unutilized fields will retain their stock captions (Client ExtraFields_StringField7, Client ExtraFields_CustomListField3, etc.)
Reservations of extra data fields for select purposes within the {{client}} CRM will be added below.

p.a: Limit per Person rules: Setting maximum purchase quantities for events or series

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will use Limit per Person rules to prevent fraud, speculative purchasing, and coupon abuse. Their Limit per Person rules will generally be set at the {{show-type-caption}} level within the Ticket product type hierarchy in order to apply as globally as possible, rarely being overridden.
Limit per Person rules only apply to primary purchases, and are not evaluated on secondary market purchases.

{{client}} take the recommended approaches to printing and access control for organizations distributing tickets on SeatGeek Open. Ticket fulfillment is {{mobile-only-or-first}}: {{most-or-all}} tickets are distributed digitally through the SeatGeek app and Account Manager, with {{some-or-no}} tickets printed physically to hard stock.
Documents and Document Types, from User reference guide: Printing
Document Dispatch (Design) rules, from User reference guide: Printing

{{client}} generally use the standard, pre-built designs for Documents such as Confirmation Emails, Draft Invoices, and other commonly printed digital documents. Cosmetic modifications will be made, such as adding their logo, labels, and verbiage.

While {{client}} will {{rarely-or-not}} distribute physical thermal tickets to customers, in cases where exceptions are made and hard-stock tickets are printed, a custom-branded design has been prepared for the Ticket document type, sized to spitter stock size for the ticket office’s thermal printers.

All document designs will be Printer-Independent designs. {{client}} may create multiple document designs as needed for different products, workflows, and/or categories of intended recipient customers. These designs can be conditionally sent to print through Document Dispatch rules. Document Dispatch rules will virtually always be set at the Document Types level, and almost never set at any level within the Product Type hierarchies (Ticket, Subscription).
Printers, from User reference guide: Printing

{{client}} practice {{mobile-only-or-first}} fulfillment. The ticket office has provisioned {{several-some-no}} physical Printers in their Unify (SRO) environment for thermal ticket printing. The ticket office have set up and will use locally-installed virtual printers for the purposes of downloading PDFs and generating digital document files, saved directly to employees' workstations' hard drives.

A typical locally-installed Printer on a workstation will be configured as a PDF Documents-typed printer, with its files set to save to a user-defined folder on their workstation that is specially dedicated to storing PDF files. This local PDF printer will receive print jobs from a locally-installed Printer Server that is running on the same workstation. {{client}} understand that each Printer’s delegating Printer Server must be running in order for print jobs to be processed by the Printer.
Printer Servers, from User reference guide: Printing
{{client}} will install Printer Servers locally on workstations where PDF printing or the generation of local files is needed.
These printer servers will almost always be configured as Windows Services; only in special cases will a printer server be installed and operate in Standalone Application mode.

p.a: SMS Ticket Collection: Sending digital tickets to customers' cell phones

ac:rich-text-body.p: As an alternative ticket fulfillment method – provided mostly as a courtesy to ticket owners who cannot access their SeatGeek accounts, don’t have a smart phone, or have other ticketing issues – {{client}} will in some cases offer to text customers their tickets via the SMS Ticket Collection feature. All box office and back office users will be trained on sending tickets via SMS to customers.
This option is offered as an alternative to traditional hard-stock thermal ticket printing.

p.a: User reference guide: SRO Built-In Access Control

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} utilize SRO Built-In Access Control for barcode generation and validation. All major events built within Unify (SRO) and hosted at {{primary-venue}} will use SRO Built-In Access Control unless otherwise specified below.
SeatGeek’s Client Success Management team is responsible for procuring scanning hardware according to the hardware credit specified in the {{client}} contract.

p.a: Fortress Access Control

ac:rich-text-body.p: The Access Control provider for {{most-or-all}} {{client}} events is Fortress, who is responsible for barcode generation, hardware procurement and configuration, and barcode validation. All major events built within Unify and hosted at {{primary-venue}} are synced to Fortress through the SeatGeek-Fortress integration.

The {{client}} Fortress server is hosted {{on-premise-or-cloud}}, and is administered by {{client-or-Fortress}}. Barcode generation and validation depend upon a consistent, high-uptime connection to the Fortress server, and {{client-or-Fortress}} is responsible for ensuring the server’s reliability.
Details of the Fortress access control arrangement are as follows:

The Access Control provider for {{most-or-all}} {{client}} {{events-caption}} is SKIDATA, who is responsible for hardware procurement and configuration and barcode validation. All major events built within Unify (SRO) and hosted at {{primary-venue}} are synced to SKIDATA through the SeatGeek-SKIDATA integration, using {{ShowTime-API-or-other}}. Unlike the SeatGeek-Fortress integration, in which Fortress both generates barcodes and validates them while scanning, Unify (SRO) is responsible for generating barcodes at print-time and sending those internally-generated barcodes to the SKIDATA server.

The {{client}} SKIDATA server is hosted {{on-premise-or-cloud}}, which is administered by the {{client}} IT department. Barcode generation and validation depend upon a consistent, high-uptime connection between Unify and the SKIDATA server, and the {{client}} IT department is responsible for ensuring the server’s reliability, security, and connectivity.
Details of the SKIDATA access control arrangement are as follows:
{{client}} uses {{lv-name}} as their Loaded Value provider.
VenueNext, a division of Shift4

p.a: https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SRN/pages/3132620805

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} offer Loaded Value to their customers using Shift4’s VenueNext platform.

VenueNext is integrated with the Unify (SRO) SeatGeek platform. Through the SeatGeek Open API, VenueNext can receive ticket-level or CRM-level data (or both), and conditionally apply benefits to purchases of food, beverage, merchandise, or other products at {{primary-venue}}. These benefits may include simple discounts, buy-one-get-one deals, or virtual in-venue currency credits that can be used at {{primary-venue}} vendors. Benefits are granted based upon a ticket’s intrinsic properties or granted to the ticket owner themselves.

The rules that govern which benefits are applied toward which in-venue purchases are worked out between the {{client}} ticket office and VenueNext. Implementation, management, monitoring, and troubleshooting of issues with VenueNext’s loaded value platform are all handled jointly and directly between {{client}} and VenueNext. SeatGeek’s role within the relationship is to transmit valid, up-to-date ticket-level and CRM-level data to VenueNext; SeatGeek does not control nor have visibility into the conditions or actions of rules within VenueNext’s system. Questions fielded by SeatGeek FS regarding loaded value redemptions will be redirected to the {{client}} ticket office.

The ways in which {{client}} collect money, issue reimbursements, report on their receivables, and perform other core Payments-related workflows adhere generally to the standard for {{league-or-vertical}} organizations.

{{client}} will be selective about which Payment Methods are availed to which users and which payment scenarios. They will configure their Payment Method Availability rules in the standard manner, adhering to SeatGeek’s suggested practice of setting Payment Method Availability rules primarily and solely at the Basket product type level, instead of (and only sometimes in conjunction with) product-level Payment Method Availability rules.
{{client}} have created and will utilize Payment Methods assigned to all three major Payment Method Types within Unify (SRO):
Online payment methods (Credit card, ACH, Direct Debit), from Payment and Reimbursement Method Types: Online and Dummy

td.p: The {{client}} organization’s OPS provider, {{ops-provider}}, will process all payments submitted via credit/debit cards through either the Unify Sales module or SeatGeek Account Manager Checkout.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Card Present (Chip and Pin) payments, from Sale Points: Associating workstations with sale points for selling and printing

td.p: Card Present payments, in which a customer physically pays through a payment terminal at the point-of-sale to complete their purchase – which is generally only done within the Walkup Sales sale mode – are also processed by {{ops-provider}}.

ac:rich-text-body.p: Dummy (offline) payments, from Payment and Reimbursement Method Types: Online and Dummy

td.p: {{client}} have created and will sometimes apply payments (and/or reimbursements) against ‘dummy’ payment methods. These payment methods will be configured under the Cash Payment Method Type.

Cash-typed payments may represent funds that have been collected/refunded through fiat currency (like actual cash). They also may represent virtual payments in which no actual money was collected at sale time, but will ultimately be settled separately (such as via checks or wire payments) post-sale.

Cash-typed offline payment methods may also be used in some workflows in which comped products are sold, but whose sale values are intentionally not set to $0 for accounting purposes. This type of dummy payment represents an ‘on-the-house’ comping, in which the actual sale value of the product sold is unadulterated, but the customer may not be directly charged to purchase it.

p.a: Payment Plans: Interest-free flexible payment options for customers

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will offer one or more Payment Plans as payment options for full {{subscriber-caption}}s and other high-value product buyers. Payment Plans are supported in both Unify Sales when selling any product through the back office, and in SeatGeek Account Manager Checkout when selling or renewing a {{subscription-caption}} online. Payment Plans defined within Unify (SRO) are not supported for single-{{event-caption}}
A typical {{client}} payment plan will be configured accordingly:

td.p: One or more OPS methods, processed by {{ops-provider}}, will be capable of paying for payment plan installments.

Some payment plans will not require a down payment. Others may set the down payment amount as a minimum X% of total or a Minimum sum of X; in cases where percentage-based down payments are required, {{client}} often set the minimal down payment to equal the effective amount of each remaining installment, though this is entirely a matter of the ticket office’s preference.

li.p: A ‘4 Month’ payment plan may be defined by {{client}} as consisting of 3 installments, with 1 initial down payment.
{{client}} set the plan’s required down payment to 25%.
If a $1000 {{subscription-caption}} is sold onto the payment plan, the payment plan will as a result consist of:

ac:rich-text-body.p: $250 down payment
+ $250 first installment
+ $250 second installment
+ $250 third (final) installment

That would cover the full $1000 payable amount, and effectively makes the down payment paid at sale time into an equal-value stand-in for a ‘first installment.' It is not technically an installment, but it is effectively handled as one that is charged upon enrollment in the payment plan.

td.p: It is also worth noting that the Minimum X% of total and Minimum sum of X required down payment options are only the minimum amounts that must be paid in order to enroll in the plan; both Unify Sales and SeatGeek Account Manager Checkout allow the customer to submit a greater-than-minimum down payment amount of their choosing, which in turn lessen the amounts they pay in future installments.

SeatGeek controls whether a given payment plan, availed within SeatGeek Account Manager Checkout, allows or disallows the submission of a greater-than-minimum down payment. {{client}} can request at any time to permit or prohibit customers from submitting custom down payment amounts when enrolling in a payment plan online.

In most cases, {{client}} set the schedule of installments collections to a Custom set of dates. This allows the ticket office to maintain a more consistent basis and reliable estimation of accounts receivable from payment plan collections on a given day, or within a given month of the year.

li.p: A 6 Month payment plan may be defined by {{client}} as consisting of 6 installments, with no required down payment.

{{client}} set the 6 installments to charge on the first business day of every month, September 1, October 2, November 1, December 1, January 2 (skipping the presumed holiday of New Years Day) and February 1.

ac:rich-text-body.p: After a large enough number of {{subscriber-caption}}s are enrolled in this payment plan, {{client}} will be able to fairly easily forecast their cash flow from payment plan collections in a given month.

td.p: The alternative installment scheduling options – Monthly, Weekly, and Bi-Weekly – are available to be used if {{client}} wish to and are just as reliable as a Custom schedule. These options effectively generate a unique installment collections schedule for every new payment plan that a customer enrolls in, with dates that are relative to the original sale (enrollment) date when the payment plan was conceived. Weekends and holidays are not skipped when this schedule is auto-generated.

li.p: A 6 Month payment plan may be defined by {{client}} as consisting of 6 installments, with no required down payment.
{{client}} set the installment schedule to charge on a Monthly basis.

ac:rich-text-body.p: A customer who signs up for this 6-month plan on August 7 will be charged on September 7, October 7, November 7, December 7, January 7 and February 7. Similarly, a different customer who signs up for the same 6-month plan two days later on August 9 will be charged on September 9, October 9, and so on.

{{client}} may enjoy the more consistent inflow of cash on a daily basis with this type of scheduling basis, with the caveat that some installments may be collected on weekends and holidays when ticket office staffing may be unavailable to respond to questions or complaints.

th.p: If on sale date some installments are past due…

td.p: In cases where a customer signs up for a payment plan that is still being offered, but whose Custom installment collections schedule contains some installments whose dates have already passed, {{client}} will typically set a payment plan to split the amount between the remaining (future) installments.

Each future installment in the plan would then be a higher effective amount than it originally would have been – for example, a $1000 plan could end up consisting of two $500 installments instead of the original schedule of 4 $250 plans – but, the benefit to this policy is that customers who sign up ‘late’ for a payment plan are not charged a prohibitively high down payment amount (Add entire amount to down payment), nor a balloon payment on their first installment (Add entire amount to first remaining installment).

p.a: Deposits and Withdrawals: Using account credits for payments and refunds

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will use {{deposit-caption}}s and {{deposit-caption}} Categories to store banked money in customers' Unify (SRO) CRM records. This money can be used towards future purchases. {{deposit-caption}}s will be created in various ways:

li.p: Conversion of dummy event tickets purchased to get onto one of {{client}} waitlists.
Reimbursement of funds paid toward cancelled tickets or other products, in lieu of reimbursing directly to the customer’s credit/debit card, or other method.
Credit generated from re-selling tickets on the SeatGeek Open Marketplace, in lieu of a direct payout to the seller’s bank account.

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} {{do-or-do-not}} plan to allow {{deposit-caption}}s to be applied toward single-game purchases on SeatGeek or back office sales of single-{{event-caption}} tickets, and will set their Payment Method Availability rules accordingly.
Otherwise, {{deposit-caption}}s will usually be withdrawable against higher-value product purchases like {{subscription-caption}}s, group outings, premium tickets, and so on.

p.a: User reference guide: Reporting (Unify)
User reference guide: Queries (Unify)

ac:rich-text-body.p: The {{client}} ticket office’s usage and builds of Reports within Unify will follow the standard patterns, and shouldn’t have many especially unique qualities.

{{client}} build and run Queries as a mechanism for client typing CRM records and for filtering reports. They have no use for the Queries module (formerly known as the Marketing module) as an actual email marketing device, as all email marketing campaigns will be administered by the {{client}} Marketing department, through a non-ticketing system.
{{client}} comply with the NFL’s mandatory reporting requirements through the following procedures:

li.p: The Potential Income Price List is assigned to all NFL games. That Price List is the same Price List that serves as the event’s Regular Event Tickets Price List.

The Regular Event Tickets Price List will have a Base Price defined in it. The Base Price’s Price at each price level will be set to match the Price value for that particular game within the context of a full season ticket sale, if it were sold as part of a new (non-renewal) full season ticket. This is especially important to configure for any events in which SeatGeekIQ has an inventory position, and is selling seats that otherwise could have been sold as part of a full season ticket.

The NFL Data Feed and NFL Associate security tokens are both granted access to any products and entities within Unify which are relevant to the NFL. Irrelevant products such as third-party events, price types and/or client types with no relationship to the football portion of the {{client}} organization’s business will be blocked from these two security tokens within Data Security.
All events within the NFL preseason, regular season, and postseason will have the ReportToNfl event tag enabled, in order for sales data for those events to be directly sent to the league office.
All {{series-caption}} containing NFL game tickets – whether empty, fixed, or flex – will have the Series is reported to league parameter enabled in the {{series-caption}} configuration page.
