p.a: Rally: Mobile tickets and custom in-app widgets for event day experiences

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} leverage SeatGeek’s Rally experience with a raft of custom widgets to promote more fan engagement on {{event-caption}} days, and to drive traffic and demand toward higher-value products. Additionally, Premium ticket owners may be shown custom Rally widgets that provide additional messaging and guest services touchpoints.
As custom Rally widgets are built for {{client}}, they will be noted and detailed below.

p.a: Rally: Mobile tickets and custom in-app widgets for event day experiences

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} leverage SeatGeek’s Rally experience with a raft of custom widgets to promote more fan engagement on {{event-caption}} days, and to drive traffic and demand toward higher-value products.
There are a few ways that Rally can be leveraged to target both new and established {{client}} fans:

li.p: Premium ticket owners may be shown custom Rally widgets that provide additional messaging about their ticket benefits and ways to reach guest services.
Interactive maps of {{primary-venue}} can be provided for wayfinding assistance.

First-time buyers/attendees – which can be identified automatically through Unify Queries or other CRM tools – could be shown widgets encouraging them to come back for an upcoming {{event-caption}}, or consider buying a partial-{{subscription-caption}} package.
Food-and-beverage in-seat ordering can be activated, so that fans can buy food delivered straight to their seats or to pick up in the concourse without having to wait in line.
Pre-{{event-caption}} or post-{{event-caption}} activities at {{primary-venue}} can be advertised, including sign-up forms or promotional offers.

Students or military veterans – also identifiable automatically through Unify Queries searching for customers with .edu email addresses, or by querying for tickets bought at price types exclusively available to active-duty military or veterans organizations – can be offered unique deals on tickets, merchandise, or other benefits through targeted widgets.

p.a: SeatGeek Account Manager: The web-based account administration experience for ticket owners

ac:rich-text-body.p: The {{client}} SeatGeek Account Manager experience will be tailored to mainly serve as a form of online, ticketing-related benefits hub for {{subscriber-caption}}s. They may maintain some evergreen, always-visible offers to drive {{subscription-caption}} sales from the Offers tab among non-{{subscriber-caption}}s.
Otherwise, all other offers – such as renewals, relocations, playoffs, etc. – will be either seasonal or ephemeral.

h2: StandardGreen SeatGeek Online Ticket Management rules

p.a: SeatGeek Account Manager: The web-based account administration experience for ticket owners

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will set their SeatGeek Online Ticket Management rules in a broadly standard way across all events. Their ticket management rules reflect their {{mobile-only-or-first}} ticketing philosophy, and their business' emphasis on timely payment collections. Below are a few high-level notes on how their ticket management rules are generally set, though specific rule builds and conditions used will vary:

li.p: PDF Viewing is forbidden in {{most-or-all}} cases.

Ticket Visibility is allowed for ticketed events, in almost all circumstances. Dummy events and other non-ticketed products that are technically sold as event tickets in Unify (SRO) are forbidden from ticket visibility in all cases.
Barcode Visibility is allowed generally, but is forbidden in certain cases.

Ticket Resale is allowed generally, but is forbidden when a customer is delinquent on payment plan installment payment(s) or their tickets are Unpaid, unless overridden. Comp tickets and employee tickets will be forbidden from resale.
Ticket Transfer is allowed generally.

ac:rich-text-body.p: They have one client type in their system, {{blocked-client-type}}, which is forbidden from every ticket management privilege with the exception of Ticket Visibility. They can see their ticket, but cannot see its barcode, and cannot transfer nor resell it. Additionally, {{client}} will set Sales Period rules and Limit per Person rules to prevent customers with this client type from buying primary tickets.

If a customer with the {{blocked-client-type}} client type comes to own a ticket by some method – such as by receiving a ticket transfer, or buying a secondary ticket – the intentionally restrictive SeatGeek Online Ticket Management rules that forbid all ticket management will force them to contact the {{client}} ticket office. Application of this client type to CRM records is very rare and is done only in circumstances where an attendee has behaved inappropriately, violated the {{client}} and/or {{primary-venue}}'s terms and conditions, or has been officially banned from attending events at {{primary-venue}}. If a customer with this client type contacts SeatGeek FS, they will be redirected to {{client}} ticket office management.

p.a: User reference guide: Amplify

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} ticket office managers have access to all Amplify tabs and permissions, including Amplify Analytics. {{client}} have also been introduced to the concept of seat-level pricing, as set within Amplify.
Ticket office management, or third-party users such as event promoters, may use this feature to set seat-level prices on Prime inventory within Amplify.

p.a: Price Floors: Setting minimum resale prices on the SeatGeek Open Marketplace
https://seatgeek.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/SGO/pages/3025960988

ac:rich-text-body.p: {{client}} will apply Price Floors to resale tickets in order to prevent too-cheap tickets from being listed on the resale market. {{para-price-floors}}

{{client}} understand that these price floors will not apply to broker listings posted on SeatGeek’s Sellerdirect platform, and will only be effective on consumer-to-consumer (Open Marketplace) listings. Officially-sanctioned broker partners (such as Eventellect) will be made aware of the {{client}} ticket office’s price floor rerquirements, and will be responsible for self-enforcing those floors when pricing their inventory on the broker tickets market.
